						<h1 id="firstHeading" class="firstHeading" lang="en"><span dir="auto">Nuclear power</span></h1>
			<div id="bodyContent">
								<div id="siteSub">From Wikipedia, the free encyclopedia</div>
								<div id="contentSub"></div>
												<div id="jump-to-nav" class="mw-jump">

				</div>
				<div id="mw-content-text" lang="en" dir="ltr" class="mw-content-ltr"><div class="dablink">"Atomic Power" redirects here. For the film, see <a href="/w/index.php?title=Atomic_Power_(film)&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Atomic Power (film) (page does not exist)">Atomic Power (film)</a>.</div>
<p><a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:About&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:About (page does not exist)">Template:About</a>
<a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Pp-semi-protected&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Pp-semi-protected (page does not exist)">Template:Pp-semi-protected</a>
</p>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:182px;"><a href="/wiki/File:Susquehanna_steam_electric_station.jpg" title="File:Susquehanna steam electric station.jpg">File:Susquehanna steam electric station.jpg</a>  <div class="thumbcaption">The <a href="/w/index.php?title=Susquehanna_Steam_Electric_Station&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Susquehanna Steam Electric Station (page does not exist)">Susquehanna Steam Electric Station</a>, a <a href="/wiki/Boiling_water_reactor" title="Boiling water reactor">boiling water reactor</a>. The reactors are located inside the rectangular <a href="/wiki/Containment_building" title="Containment building">containment buildings</a> towards the front of the <a href="/wiki/Cooling_tower" title="Cooling tower">cooling towers</a>. The power station produces 63 million <a href="/wiki/Kilowatt_hour" title="Kilowatt hour">units of electricity</a> per day.</div></div></div>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:182px;"><a href="/wiki/File:TaskForce_One.jpg" title="File:TaskForce One.jpg">File:TaskForce One.jpg</a>  <div class="thumbcaption">American nuclear powered ships,(top to bottom) cruisers <a href="/wiki/USS_Bainbridge_(CGN-25)" title="USS Bainbridge (CGN-25)">USS <i>Bainbridge</i></a>, the <a href="/wiki/USS_Long_Beach_(CGN-9)" title="USS Long Beach (CGN-9)">USS <i>Long Beach</i></a> and the <i><a href="/wiki/USS_Enterprise_(CVN-65)" title="USS Enterprise (CVN-65)">USS Enterprise</a></i>, the <a href="/w/index.php?title=List_of_longest_naval_ships&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="List of longest naval ships (page does not exist)">longest ever naval vessel</a>, and the first nuclear-powered <a href="/wiki/Aircraft_carrier" title="Aircraft carrier">aircraft carrier</a>. Picture taken in 1964 during a record setting voyage of 26,540 nmi (49,190 km) around the world in 65 days without refueling. Crew members are spelling out <a href="/wiki/Albert_Einstein" title="Albert Einstein">Einstein</a>'s <a href="/w/index.php?title=Mass-energy_equivalence&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Mass-energy equivalence (page does not exist)">mass-energy equivalence</a> formula <i>E&#160;=&#160;mc<sup>2</sup></i> on the flight deck.</div></div></div>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:182px;"><a href="/wiki/File:NSF_picture_of_Yamal.jpg" title="File:NSF picture of Yamal.jpg">File:NSF picture of Yamal.jpg</a>  <div class="thumbcaption">The Russian <a href="/wiki/Nuclear-powered_icebreaker" title="Nuclear-powered icebreaker">nuclear-powered icebreaker</a> <a href="/wiki/Yamal_(icebreaker)" title="Yamal (icebreaker)">NS Yamal</a> on a joint scientific expedition with the <a href="/wiki/National_Science_Foundation" title="National Science Foundation">NSF</a> in 1994.</div></div></div>
<p><b>Nuclear power</b>, or <b>nuclear <a href="/wiki/Energy" title="Energy">energy</a></b>, is the use of <a href="/w/index.php?title=Nuclear_binding_energy&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Nuclear binding energy (page does not exist)">exothermic nuclear processes</a>,<sup id="cite_ref-nuclearEnergy-tx_1-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-nuclearEnergy-tx-1">[1]</a></sup> to generate useful <a href="/w/index.php?title=Heat&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Heat (page does not exist)">heat</a> and <a href="/wiki/Electricity" title="Electricity">electricity</a>. The term includes <a href="/wiki/Nuclear_fission" title="Nuclear fission">nuclear fission</a>, <a href="/wiki/Nuclear_decay" title="Nuclear decay" class="mw-redirect">nuclear decay</a> and <a href="/wiki/Nuclear_fusion" title="Nuclear fusion">nuclear fusion</a>. Presently the <a href="/wiki/Nuclear_fission" title="Nuclear fission">nuclear fission</a> of elements in the <a href="/wiki/Actinide#Applications" title="Actinide">actinide</a> series of the <a href="/wiki/Periodic_table" title="Periodic table">periodic table</a> produce the vast majority of nuclear energy in the direct service of humankind, with <a href="/wiki/Nuclear_decay" title="Nuclear decay" class="mw-redirect">nuclear decay</a> processes, primarily in the form of <a href="/wiki/Geothermal_energy" title="Geothermal energy">geothermal energy</a>, and <a href="/wiki/Radioisotope_thermoelectric_generator" title="Radioisotope thermoelectric generator">radioisotope thermoelectric generators</a>, in niche uses making up the rest. <a href="/wiki/Nuclear_power_plant" title="Nuclear power plant">Nuclear (fission) power stations</a>, excluding the contribution from <a href="/wiki/Nuclear_marine_propulsion" title="Nuclear marine propulsion">naval nuclear fission reactors</a>, provided about 5.7% of the world's <a href="/wiki/Energy" title="Energy">energy</a> and 13% of the world's electricity in 2012.<sup id="cite_ref-2" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-2">[2]</a></sup> In 2013, the <a href="/wiki/International_Atomic_Energy_Agency" title="International Atomic Energy Agency">IAEA</a> report that there are 437&#160;operational nuclear power reactors,<sup id="cite_ref-iaea.org_3-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-iaea.org-3">[3]</a></sup> in <a href="/w/index.php?title=Nuclear_power_by_country&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Nuclear power by country (page does not exist)">31&#160;countries</a>,<sup id="cite_ref-UIC_4-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-UIC-4">[4]</a></sup>  although not every reactor is producing electricity.<sup id="cite_ref-5" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-5">[5]</a></sup> In addition, there are approximately 140 naval vessels using <a href="/wiki/Nuclear_propulsion" title="Nuclear propulsion">nuclear propulsion</a> in operation, powered by some 180 reactors.<sup id="cite_ref-6" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-6">[6]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-7" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-7">[7]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-8" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-8">[8]</a></sup> As of 2013, attaining a <a href="/wiki/Joint_European_Torus" title="Joint European Torus">net energy gain</a> from sustained <a href="/wiki/Nuclear_fusion" title="Nuclear fusion">nuclear fusion</a> reactions, excluding natural fusion power sources such as the <a href="/wiki/Sun" title="Sun">Sun</a>, remains an ongoing area of international <a href="/wiki/International_Thermonuclear_Experimental_Reactor" title="International Thermonuclear Experimental Reactor" class="mw-redirect">physics</a> and <a href="/w/index.php?title=International_Fusion_Materials_Irradiation_Facility&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="International Fusion Materials Irradiation Facility (page does not exist)">engineering research</a>. More than 60 years after the first attempts, commercial fusion power production remains unlikely before 2050.<sup id="cite_ref-ITERorg_9-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-ITERorg-9">[9]</a></sup>
</p><p>There is an ongoing <a href="/w/index.php?title=Nuclear_power_debate&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Nuclear power debate (page does not exist)">debate about nuclear power</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-10" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-10">[10]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-jstor.org_11-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-jstor.org-11">[11]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-A_Reasonable_Bet_on_Nuclear_Power_12-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-A_Reasonable_Bet_on_Nuclear_Power-12">[12]</a></sup>  Proponents, such as the <a href="/w/index.php?title=World_Nuclear_Association&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="World Nuclear Association (page does not exist)">World Nuclear Association</a>, the <a href="/wiki/International_Atomic_Energy_Agency" title="International Atomic Energy Agency">IAEA</a> and <a href="/w/index.php?title=Environmentalists_for_Nuclear_Energy&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Environmentalists for Nuclear Energy (page does not exist)">Environmentalists for Nuclear Energy</a> contend that nuclear power is a safe, <a href="/wiki/Sustainable_energy" title="Sustainable energy">sustainable</a> energy source that reduces <a href="/w/index.php?title=Carbon_emissions&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Carbon emissions (page does not exist)">carbon emissions</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-bloomberg.com_13-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-bloomberg.com-13">[13]</a></sup> <a href="/w/index.php?title=Anti-nuclear_movement&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Anti-nuclear movement (page does not exist)">Opponents</a>, such as <a href="/wiki/Greenpeace_International" title="Greenpeace International" class="mw-redirect">Greenpeace International</a> and <a href="/w/index.php?title=Nuclear_Information_and_Resource_Service&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Nuclear Information and Resource Service (page does not exist)">NIRS</a>, contend that nuclear power poses many threats to <a href="/w/index.php?title=Environmental_radioactivity&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Environmental radioactivity (page does not exist)">people and the environment</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-Share_14-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Share-14">[14]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-NC_WARN_.C2.BB_Nuclear_Power_15-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-NC_WARN_.C2.BB_Nuclear_Power-15">[15]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-Sturgis_16-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Sturgis-16">[16]</a></sup>
</p><p><a href="/wiki/Nuclear_and_radiation_accidents" title="Nuclear and radiation accidents">Nuclear power plant accidents</a> include the <a href="/w/index.php?title=Chernobyl_disaster&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Chernobyl disaster (page does not exist)">Chernobyl disaster</a> (1986), <a href="/w/index.php?title=Fukushima_Daiichi_nuclear_disaster&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Fukushima Daiichi nuclear disaster (page does not exist)">Fukushima Daiichi nuclear disaster</a> (2011), and the <a href="/wiki/Three_Mile_Island_accident" title="Three Mile Island accident">Three Mile Island accident</a> (1979).<sup id="cite_ref-timenuke_17-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-timenuke-17">[17]</a></sup> There have also been some nuclear submarine accidents.<sup id="cite_ref-timenuke_17-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-timenuke-17">[17]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-rad_18-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-rad-18">[18]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-johnston2007_19-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-johnston2007-19">[19]</a></sup> In terms of lives lost per unit of energy generated, analysis has determined that nuclear power has caused less fatalities per unit of energy generated than the other major sources of energy generation. Energy production from <a href="/wiki/Coal" title="Coal">coal</a>, <a href="/wiki/Petroleum" title="Petroleum">petroleum</a>, <a href="/wiki/Natural_gas" title="Natural gas">natural gas</a> and <a href="/wiki/Hydropower" title="Hydropower">hydropower</a> has caused a greater number of fatalities per unit of energy generated due to <a href="/w/index.php?title=Air_pollution&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Air pollution (page does not exist)">air pollution</a> and <a href="/w/index.php?title=Energy_accidents&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Energy accidents (page does not exist)">energy accident</a> effects.<sup id="cite_ref-autogenerated2007_20-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-autogenerated2007-20">[20]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-without_the_hot_air_21-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-without_the_hot_air-21">[21]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-22" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-22">[22]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-theage2006_23-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-theage2006-23">[23]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-tandfonline1_24-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-tandfonline1-24">[24]</a></sup> However, the economic costs of nuclear power accidents is high, and meltdowns can take decades to clean up. The human costs of evacuations of affected populations and lost livelihoods is also significant.<sup id="cite_ref-Richard_Schiffman_25-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Richard_Schiffman-25">[25]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-Martin_Fackler_26-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Martin_Fackler-26">[26]</a></sup>
</p><p>Along with other sustainable energy sources, nuclear power is a <a href="/w/index.php?title=Low_carbon_power_generation&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Low carbon power generation (page does not exist)">low carbon power generation</a> method of producing electricity, with an analysis of the literature on its <a href="/w/index.php?title=Life_cycle_assessment&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Life cycle assessment (page does not exist)">total life cycle</a> <a href="/wiki/Emission_intensity" title="Emission intensity">emission intensity</a> finding that it is similar to other renewable sources in a comparison of <a href="/w/index.php?title=Greenhouse_gas&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Greenhouse gas (page does not exist)">greenhouse gas</a>(GHG) emissions per unit of energy generated.<sup id="cite_ref-27" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-27">[27]</a></sup> With this translating into, from the beginning of <a href="/wiki/Nuclear_power_station" title="Nuclear power station" class="mw-redirect">nuclear power station</a> commercialization in the 1970s, having prevented the emission of approximately 64 <a href="/wiki/Gigaton" title="Gigaton" class="mw-redirect">gigatonnes</a> of <a href="/w/index.php?title=Carbon_dioxide_equivalent&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Carbon dioxide equivalent (page does not exist)">carbon dioxide equivalent</a>(GtCO2-eq) <a href="/wiki/Greenhouse_gases" title="Greenhouse gases" class="mw-redirect">greenhouse gases</a>, gases that would have otherwise resulted from the burning of <a href="/wiki/Fossil_fuel" title="Fossil fuel">fossil fuels</a> in <a href="/w/index.php?title=Thermal_power_station&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Thermal power station (page does not exist)">thermal power stations</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-28" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-28">[28]</a></sup>
</p><p>As of 2012, according to the <a href="/wiki/IAEA" title="IAEA" class="mw-redirect">IAEA</a>, worldwide there were 68 civil nuclear power reactors under construction in 15 countries,<sup id="cite_ref-iaea.org_3-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-iaea.org-3">[3]</a></sup> approximately 28 of which in the <a href="/wiki/Peoples_Republic_of_China" title="Peoples Republic of China" class="mw-redirect">Peoples Republic of China</a> (PRC), with the most recent nuclear power reactor, as of May 2013, to be connected to the <a href="/w/index.php?title=Electrical_grid&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Electrical grid (page does not exist)">electrical grid</a>, occurring on February 17, 2013 in <a href="/w/index.php?title=Hongyanhe_Nuclear_Power_Plant&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Hongyanhe Nuclear Power Plant (page does not exist)">Hongyanhe Nuclear Power Plant</a> in the PRC.<sup id="cite_ref-29" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-29">[29]</a></sup> In the <a href="/wiki/USA" title="USA" class="mw-redirect">USA</a>, two new <a href="/w/index.php?title=Generation_III_reactor&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Generation III reactor (page does not exist)">Generation III reactors</a> are under construction at <a href="/w/index.php?title=Vogtle&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Vogtle (page does not exist)">Vogtle</a>. U.S. nuclear industry officials expect five new reactors to enter service by 2020, all at existing plants.<sup id="cite_ref-us12_30-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-us12-30">[30]</a></sup> In 2013, four aging, uncompetitive, reactors were permanently closed.<sup id="cite_ref-Mark_Cooper_31-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Mark_Cooper-31">[31]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-mw11111_32-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-mw11111-32">[32]</a></sup>
</p><p>Japan's 2011 <a href="/w/index.php?title=Fukushima_Daiichi_nuclear_disaster&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Fukushima Daiichi nuclear disaster (page does not exist)">Fukushima Daiichi nuclear disaster</a>, which occurred in a reactor design from the <a href="/w/index.php?title=Generation_II_reactor&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Generation II reactor (page does not exist)">1960s</a>, prompted a rethink of <a href="/w/index.php?title=Nuclear_safety&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Nuclear safety (page does not exist)">nuclear safety</a> and <a href="/w/index.php?title=Nuclear_energy_policy&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Nuclear energy policy (page does not exist)">nuclear energy policy</a> in many countries.<sup id="cite_ref-sciamer2011_33-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-sciamer2011-33">[33]</a></sup> Germany decided to close all its reactors by 2022, and Italy has banned nuclear power.<sup id="cite_ref-sciamer2011_33-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-sciamer2011-33">[33]</a></sup> Following Fukushima, in 2011 the <a href="/wiki/International_Energy_Agency" title="International Energy Agency">International Energy Agency</a> halved its estimate of additional nuclear generating capacity to be built by 2035.<sup id="cite_ref-economist-20110428_34-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-economist-20110428-34">[34]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-late_35-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-late-35">[35]</a></sup>
</p>

<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="Use">Use</span></h2>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:182px;"><a href="/wiki/File:World_energy_consumption_outlook.png" title="File:World energy consumption outlook.png">File:World energy consumption outlook.png</a>  <div class="thumbcaption">Historical and projected world energy use by energy source, 1990-2035, Source: International Energy Outlook 2011, <a href="/wiki/Energy_Information_Administration" title="Energy Information Administration">EIA</a>.</div></div></div>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:182px;"><a href="/wiki/File:Nuclear_power_capacity_and_generation.png" title="File:Nuclear power capacity and generation.png">File:Nuclear power capacity and generation.png</a>  <div class="thumbcaption">Nuclear power installed capacity and generation, 1980 to 2010 (EIA).</div></div></div>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:182px;"><a href="/wiki/File:Top_5_Nuclear_Energy_Producing_Countries.png" title="File:Top 5 Nuclear Energy Producing Countries.png">File:Top 5 Nuclear Energy Producing Countries.png</a>  <div class="thumbcaption">Trends in the top five nuclear-energy producing countries (US EIA data)</div></div></div>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:182px;"><a href="/wiki/File:Nuclear_power_station.svg" title="File:Nuclear power station.svg">File:Nuclear power station.svg</a>  <div class="thumbcaption">The status of nuclear power globally<br />(click image for legend)</div></div></div>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:182px;"><a href="/wiki/File:Nuclear_power_percentage.svg" title="File:Nuclear power percentage.svg">File:Nuclear power percentage.svg</a>  <div class="thumbcaption">Percentage of power produced by nuclear power plants</div></div></div>
<p><a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Rellink&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Rellink (page does not exist)">Template:Rellink</a>
In 2011 nuclear power provided 10% of the world's electricity<sup id="cite_ref-oecd_pdf_36-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-oecd_pdf-36">[36]</a></sup> In 2007, the <a href="/wiki/International_Atomic_Energy_Agency" title="International Atomic Energy Agency">IAEA</a> reported there were 439&#160;nuclear power reactors in operation in the world,<sup id="cite_ref-iaea_reactors_37-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-iaea_reactors-37">[37]</a></sup> operating in 31&#160;countries.<sup id="cite_ref-UIC_4-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-UIC-4">[4]</a></sup> However, many have now ceased operation in the wake of the Fukushima nuclear disaster while they are assessed for safety. In 2011 worldwide nuclear output fell by 4.3%, the largest decline on record, on the back of sharp declines in Japan (-44.3%) and Germany (-23.2%).<sup id="cite_ref-bp_energy_review_38-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-bp_energy_review-38">[38]</a></sup>
</p><p>Since commercial nuclear energy began in the mid-1950s, 2008 was the first year that no new nuclear power plant was connected to the grid, although two were connected in 2009.<sup id="cite_ref-tf2010_39-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-tf2010-39">[39]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-40" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-40">[40]</a></sup>
</p><p>Annual generation of nuclear power has been on a slight downward trend since 2007, decreasing 1.8% in 2009 to 2558 TWh with nuclear power meeting 13–14% of the world's electricity demand.<sup id="cite_ref-WNAMay_41-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-WNAMay-41">[41]</a></sup> One factor in the nuclear power percentage decrease since 2007 has been the prolonged shutdown of large reactors at the <a href="/w/index.php?title=Kashiwazaki-Kariwa_Nuclear_Power_Plant&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Kashiwazaki-Kariwa Nuclear Power Plant (page does not exist)">Kashiwazaki-Kariwa Nuclear Power Plant</a> in Japan following the <a href="/w/index.php?title=2007_Ch%C5%ABetsu_offshore_earthquake&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="2007 Chūetsu offshore earthquake (page does not exist)">Niigata-Chuetsu-Oki earthquake</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-WNAMay_41-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-WNAMay-41">[41]</a></sup>
</p><p>The United States produces the most nuclear energy, with nuclear power providing 19%<sup id="cite_ref-42" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-42">[42]</a></sup> of the electricity it consumes, while France produces the highest percentage of its electrical energy from nuclear reactors—80% as of 2006.<sup id="cite_ref-npr20060501_43-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-npr20060501-43">[43]</a></sup> In the <a href="/wiki/European_Union" title="European Union">European Union</a> as a whole, nuclear energy provides 30% of the electricity.<sup id="cite_ref-44" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-44">[44]</a></sup> <a href="/w/index.php?title=Nuclear_energy_policy&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Nuclear energy policy (page does not exist)">Nuclear energy policy</a> differs among European Union countries, and some, such as <a href="/w/index.php?title=Austria&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Austria (page does not exist)">Austria</a>, <a href="/w/index.php?title=Estonia&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Estonia (page does not exist)">Estonia</a>, <a href="/wiki/Ireland" title="Ireland">Ireland</a> and <a href="/wiki/Italy" title="Italy">Italy</a>, have no active nuclear power stations. In comparison, France has a large number of these plants, with 16 multi-unit stations in current use.
</p><p>In the US, while the <a href="/w/index.php?title=Coal_plant&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Coal plant (page does not exist)">coal and gas electricity industry</a> is projected to be worth $85 billion by 2013, nuclear power generators are forecast to be worth $18 billion.<sup id="cite_ref-45" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-45">[45]</a></sup>
</p><p>Many <a href="/wiki/Military" title="Military">military</a> and some civilian (such as some <a href="/wiki/Icebreaker" title="Icebreaker">icebreaker</a>) ships use <a href="/wiki/Nuclear_marine_propulsion" title="Nuclear marine propulsion">nuclear marine propulsion</a>, a form of <a href="/wiki/Nuclear_propulsion" title="Nuclear propulsion">nuclear propulsion</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-46" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-46">[46]</a></sup> A few space vehicles have been launched using full-fledged <a href="/wiki/Nuclear_reactor" title="Nuclear reactor">nuclear reactors</a>: 33 reactors belong to the Soviet <a href="/w/index.php?title=RORSAT&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="RORSAT (page does not exist)">RORSAT</a> series and one was the American <a href="/wiki/SNAP-10A" title="SNAP-10A">SNAP-10A</a>.
</p><p>International research is continuing into safety improvements such as <a href="/w/index.php?title=Passively_safe&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Passively safe (page does not exist)">passively safe</a> plants,<sup id="cite_ref-David_Baurac_2002_47-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-David_Baurac_2002-47">[47]</a></sup> the use of <a href="/wiki/Nuclear_fusion" title="Nuclear fusion">nuclear fusion</a>, and additional uses of process heat such as <a href="/wiki/Water_splitting#Nuclear-thermal" title="Water splitting">hydrogen production</a> (in support of a <a href="/wiki/Hydrogen_economy" title="Hydrogen economy">hydrogen economy</a>), for <a href="/wiki/Desalination" title="Desalination">desalinating</a> sea water, and for use in <a href="/wiki/District_heating" title="District heating">district heating</a> systems.
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Use_in_space">Use in space</span></h3>
<p><a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Rellink&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Rellink (page does not exist)">Template:Rellink</a>
Both <a href="/wiki/Nuclear_fission" title="Nuclear fission">fission</a> and fusion appear promising for <a href="/wiki/Spacecraft_propulsion" title="Spacecraft propulsion">space propulsion</a> applications, generating higher mission velocities with less <a href="/wiki/Reaction_mass" title="Reaction mass" class="mw-redirect">reaction mass</a>. This is due to the much higher energy density of nuclear reactions: some 7 orders of magnitude (10,000,000 times) more energetic than the chemical reactions which power the current generation of rockets.
</p><p><a href="/wiki/Radioactive_decay" title="Radioactive decay">Radioactive decay</a> has been used on a relatively small scale (few kW), mostly to power <a href="/w/index.php?title=Space_mission&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Space mission (page does not exist)">space missions</a> and experiments by using <a href="/wiki/Radioisotope_thermoelectric_generator" title="Radioisotope thermoelectric generator">radioisotope thermoelectric generators</a> such as those developed at <a href="/wiki/Idaho_National_Laboratory#Space_and_Security_Power_Systems_Facility" title="Idaho National Laboratory">Idaho National Laboratory</a>.
</p>
<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="History">History</span></h2>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Origins">Origins</span></h3>
<p><a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Rellink&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Rellink (page does not exist)">Template:Rellink</a>
The pursuit of nuclear energy for <a href="/wiki/Electricity_generation" title="Electricity generation">electricity generation</a> began soon after the discovery in the early 20th century that <a href="/wiki/Radioactive" title="Radioactive" class="mw-redirect">radioactive</a> elements, such as <a href="/wiki/Radium" title="Radium">radium</a>, released immense amounts of energy, according to the principle of <a href="/wiki/Mass%E2%80%93energy_equivalence" title="Mass–energy equivalence">mass–energy equivalence</a>. However, means of harnessing such energy was impractical, because intensely radioactive elements were, by their very nature, short-lived (high energy release is correlated with short <a href="/wiki/Half-life" title="Half-life">half-lives</a>). However, the dream of harnessing "atomic energy" was quite strong, even though it was dismissed by such fathers of <a href="/wiki/Nuclear_physics" title="Nuclear physics">nuclear physics</a> like <a href="/wiki/Ernest_Rutherford" title="Ernest Rutherford">Ernest Rutherford</a> as "moonshine."<sup id="cite_ref-48" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-48">[48]</a></sup> This situation, however, changed in the late 1930s, with the discovery of <a href="/wiki/Nuclear_fission" title="Nuclear fission">nuclear fission</a>.
</p><p>In 1932, <a href="/wiki/James_Chadwick" title="James Chadwick">James Chadwick</a> discovered the <a href="/wiki/Neutron" title="Neutron">neutron</a>,<sup id="cite_ref-49" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-49">[49]</a></sup> which was immediately recognized as a potential tool for nuclear experimentation because of its lack of an electric charge. Experimentation with bombardment of materials with neutrons led <a href="/wiki/Fr%C3%A9d%C3%A9ric_Joliot-Curie" title="Frédéric Joliot-Curie">Frédéric</a> and <a href="/wiki/Ir%C3%A8ne_Joliot-Curie" title="Irène Joliot-Curie">Irène Joliot-Curie</a> to discover <a href="/w/index.php?title=Induced_radioactivity&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Induced radioactivity (page does not exist)">induced radioactivity</a> in 1934, which allowed the creation of radium-like elements at much less the price of natural radium.<sup id="cite_ref-50" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-50">[50]</a></sup> Further work by <a href="/wiki/Enrico_Fermi" title="Enrico Fermi">Enrico Fermi</a> in the 1930s focused on using <a href="/wiki/Slow_neutron" title="Slow neutron" class="mw-redirect">slow neutrons</a> to increase the effectiveness of induced radioactivity. Experiments bombarding uranium with neutrons led Fermi to believe he had created a new, transuranic element, which was dubbed <a href="/w/index.php?title=Hesperium&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Hesperium (page does not exist)">hesperium</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-Np_51-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Np-51">[51]</a></sup>
</p>
<div class="thumb tleft"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:182px;"><a href="/wiki/File:First_nuclear_chain_reaction.jpg" title="File:First nuclear chain reaction.jpg">File:First nuclear chain reaction.jpg</a>  <div class="thumbcaption">December 2, 1942. A depiction of the scene when scientists observed the world's first man made nuclear reactor, the <a href="/wiki/Chicago_Pile-1" title="Chicago Pile-1">Chicago Pile-1</a>, as it became self-sustaining/critical at the <a href="/wiki/University_of_Chicago" title="University of Chicago">University of Chicago</a>.</div></div></div>
<p>But in 1938, German chemists <a href="/wiki/Otto_Hahn" title="Otto Hahn">Otto Hahn</a><sup id="cite_ref-52" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-52">[52]</a></sup> and <a href="/wiki/Fritz_Strassmann" title="Fritz Strassmann">Fritz Strassmann</a>, along with Austrian physicist <a href="/wiki/Lise_Meitner" title="Lise Meitner">Lise Meitner</a><sup id="cite_ref-53" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-53">[53]</a></sup> and Meitner's nephew, <a href="/wiki/Otto_Robert_Frisch" title="Otto Robert Frisch">Otto Robert Frisch</a>,<sup id="cite_ref-54" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-54">[54]</a></sup> conducted experiments with the products of neutron-bombarded uranium, as a means of further investigating Fermi's claims. They determined that the relatively tiny neutron split the nucleus of the massive uranium atoms into two roughly equal pieces, contradicting Fermi.<sup id="cite_ref-Np_51-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Np-51">[51]</a></sup> This was an extremely surprising result: all other forms of <a href="/wiki/Nuclear_decay" title="Nuclear decay" class="mw-redirect">nuclear decay</a> involved only small changes to the mass of the nucleus, whereas this process—dubbed "fission" as a <a href="/wiki/Binary_fission" title="Binary fission" class="mw-redirect">reference to biology</a>—involved a complete rupture of the nucleus. Numerous scientists, including <a href="/wiki/Le%C3%B3_Szil%C3%A1rd" title="Leó Szilárd">Leó Szilárd</a>, who was one of the first, recognized that if fission reactions released additional neutrons, a self-sustaining <a href="/wiki/Nuclear_chain_reaction" title="Nuclear chain reaction">nuclear chain reaction</a> could result. Once this was experimentally confirmed and announced by Frédéric Joliot-Curie in 1939, scientists in many countries (including the United States, the United Kingdom, France, Germany, and the Soviet Union) petitioned their governments for support of nuclear fission research, just on the cusp of World War II, for the development of a nuclear weapon.<sup id="cite_ref-55" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-55">[55]</a></sup>
</p><p>In the United States, where Fermi and Szilárd had both emigrated, this led to the creation of the first man-made reactor, known as <a href="/wiki/Chicago_Pile-1" title="Chicago Pile-1">Chicago Pile-1</a>, which achieved <a href="/wiki/Critical_mass" title="Critical mass">criticality</a> on December 2, 1942. This work became part of the <a href="/wiki/Manhattan_Project" title="Manhattan Project">Manhattan Project</a>, which made <a href="/wiki/Enriched_uranium" title="Enriched uranium">enriched uranium</a> and built large reactors to breed <a href="/w/index.php?title=Plutonium&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Plutonium (page does not exist)">plutonium</a> for use in the first <a href="/wiki/Nuclear_weapon" title="Nuclear weapon">nuclear weapons</a>, which were <a href="/w/index.php?title=Atomic_bombings_of_Hiroshima_and_Nagasaki&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Atomic bombings of Hiroshima and Nagasaki (page does not exist)">used on the cities of Hiroshima and Nagasaki</a>.
</p>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:182px;"><a href="/wiki/File:First_four_nuclear_lit_bulbs.jpeg" title="File:First four nuclear lit bulbs.jpeg">File:First four nuclear lit bulbs.jpeg</a>  <div class="thumbcaption">The first light bulbs ever lit by electricity generated by nuclear power at <a href="/wiki/EBR-1" title="EBR-1" class="mw-redirect">EBR-1</a> at <a href="/wiki/Argonne_National_Laboratory" title="Argonne National Laboratory">Argonne National Laboratory-West</a>, December 20, 1951.</div></div></div>
<p>After World War II, the prospects of using "atomic energy" for good, rather than simply for war, was advocated as a reason not to keep all nuclear research controlled by military organizations. However, most scientists agreed that civilian nuclear power would take at least a decade to master, and the fact that nuclear reactors also produced weapons-usable plutonium created a situation in which most national governments (such as those in the United States, the United Kingdom, Canada, and the USSR) attempted to keep reactor research under strict government control and classification. In the United States, reactor research was conducted by the <a href="/wiki/U.S._Atomic_Energy_Commission" title="U.S. Atomic Energy Commission" class="mw-redirect">U.S. Atomic Energy Commission</a>, primarily at <a href="/wiki/Oak_Ridge,_Tennessee" title="Oak Ridge, Tennessee">Oak Ridge, Tennessee</a>, <a href="/wiki/Hanford_Site" title="Hanford Site">Hanford Site</a>, and <a href="/wiki/Argonne_National_Laboratory" title="Argonne National Laboratory">Argonne National Laboratory</a>.
</p><p>Work in the United States, United Kingdom, Canada,<sup id="cite_ref-56" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-56">[56]</a></sup> and USSR proceeded over the course of the late 1940s and early 1950s. Electricity was generated for the first time by a nuclear reactor on December 20, 1951, at the <a href="/w/index.php?title=EBR-I&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="EBR-I (page does not exist)">EBR-I</a> experimental station near <a href="/wiki/Arco,_Idaho" title="Arco, Idaho">Arco, Idaho</a>, which initially produced about 100&#160;kW.<sup id="cite_ref-57" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-57">[57]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-58" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-58">[58]</a></sup> Work was also strongly researched in the US on <a href="/wiki/Nuclear_marine_propulsion" title="Nuclear marine propulsion">nuclear marine propulsion</a>, with a test reactor being developed by 1953 (eventually, the <a href="/wiki/USS_Nautilus_(SSN-571)" title="USS Nautilus (SSN-571)">USS Nautilus</a>, the first nuclear-powered submarine, would launch in 1955).<sup id="cite_ref-59" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-59">[59]</a></sup> In 1953, US President <a href="/wiki/Dwight_Eisenhower" title="Dwight Eisenhower" class="mw-redirect">Dwight Eisenhower</a> gave his "<a href="/wiki/Atoms_for_Peace" title="Atoms for Peace">Atoms for Peace</a>" speech at the <a href="/wiki/United_Nations" title="United Nations">United Nations</a>, emphasizing the need to develop "peaceful" uses of nuclear power quickly. This was followed by the <a href="/w/index.php?title=Atomic_Energy_Act_of_1954&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Atomic Energy Act of 1954 (page does not exist)">1954 Amendments to the Atomic Energy Act</a> which allowed rapid declassification of U.S. reactor technology and encouraged development by the private sector.
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Early_years">Early years</span></h3>
<p>On June 27, 1954, the <a href="/wiki/USSR" title="USSR" class="mw-redirect">USSR</a>'s <a href="/w/index.php?title=Obninsk_Nuclear_Power_Plant&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Obninsk Nuclear Power Plant (page does not exist)">Obninsk Nuclear Power Plant</a> became the world's first nuclear power plant to generate electricity for a <a href="/wiki/Power_grid" title="Power grid" class="mw-redirect">power grid</a>, and produced around 5 megawatts of electric power.<sup id="cite_ref-IAEANews_60-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-IAEANews-60">[60]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-WNA_61-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-WNA-61">[61]</a></sup>
</p><p>Later in 1954, <a href="/wiki/Lewis_Strauss" title="Lewis Strauss">Lewis Strauss</a>, then chairman of the <a href="/wiki/United_States_Atomic_Energy_Commission" title="United States Atomic Energy Commission">United States Atomic Energy Commission</a> (U.S. AEC, forerunner of the U.S. <a href="/wiki/Nuclear_Regulatory_Commission" title="Nuclear Regulatory Commission">Nuclear Regulatory Commission</a> and the <a href="/wiki/United_States_Department_of_Energy" title="United States Department of Energy">United States Department of Energy</a>) spoke of electricity in the future being "<a href="/w/index.php?title=Too_cheap_to_meter&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Too cheap to meter (page does not exist)">too cheap to meter</a>".<sup id="cite_ref-thisdayinquotes_62-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-thisdayinquotes-62">[62]</a></sup> Strauss was very likely referring to hydrogen fusion<sup id="cite_ref-63" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-63">[63]</a></sup> —which was secretly being developed as part of <a href="/wiki/Project_Sherwood" title="Project Sherwood">Project Sherwood</a> at the time—but Strauss's statement was interpreted as a promise of very cheap energy from nuclear fission. The U.S. AEC itself had issued far more realistic testimony regarding nuclear fission to the U.S. Congress only months before, projecting that "costs can be brought down... [to]... about the same as the cost of electricity from conventional sources..." <sup id="cite_ref-64" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-64">[64]</a></sup> Significant disappointment would develop later on, when the new nuclear plants did not provide energy "too cheap to meter."
</p><p>In 1955 the <a href="/wiki/United_Nations" title="United Nations">United Nations</a>' "First Geneva Conference", then the world's largest gathering of scientists and engineers, met to explore the technology. In 1957 <a href="/wiki/EURATOM" title="EURATOM" class="mw-redirect">EURATOM</a> was launched alongside the <a href="/wiki/European_Economic_Community" title="European Economic Community">European Economic Community</a> (the latter is now the European Union). The same year also saw the launch of the <a href="/wiki/International_Atomic_Energy_Agency" title="International Atomic Energy Agency">International Atomic Energy Agency</a> (IAEA).
</p>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:182px;"><a href="/wiki/File:Shippingport_Reactor.jpg" title="File:Shippingport Reactor.jpg">File:Shippingport Reactor.jpg</a>  <div class="thumbcaption">The <a href="/wiki/Shippingport_Atomic_Power_Station" title="Shippingport Atomic Power Station">Shippingport Atomic Power Station</a> in <a href="/wiki/Shippingport,_Pennsylvania" title="Shippingport, Pennsylvania">Shippingport, Pennsylvania</a> was the first commercial reactor in the USA and was opened in 1957.</div></div></div>
<p>The world's first commercial nuclear power station, <a href="/w/index.php?title=Calder_Hall_nuclear_power_station&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Calder Hall nuclear power station (page does not exist)">Calder Hall</a> at Windscale, England, was opened in 1956 with an initial capacity of 50 MW (later 200 MW).<sup id="cite_ref-Kragh_65-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Kragh-65">[65]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-bbc17oct_66-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-bbc17oct-66">[66]</a></sup> The first commercial nuclear generator to become operational in the United States was the <a href="/w/index.php?title=Shippingport_Reactor&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Shippingport Reactor (page does not exist)">Shippingport Reactor</a> (<a href="/wiki/Pennsylvania" title="Pennsylvania">Pennsylvania</a>, December 1957).
</p><p>One of the first organizations to develop nuclear power was the <a href="/w/index.php?title=United_States_Navy&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="United States Navy (page does not exist)">U.S. Navy</a>, for the purpose of propelling <a href="/wiki/Submarine" title="Submarine">submarines</a> and <a href="/wiki/Aircraft_carrier" title="Aircraft carrier">aircraft carriers</a>. The first nuclear-powered submarine, <a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:USS&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:USS (page does not exist)">Template:USS</a>, was put to sea in December 1954.<sup id="cite_ref-iaeapdf_67-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-iaeapdf-67">[67]</a></sup> Two U.S. nuclear submarines, <a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:USS&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:USS (page does not exist)">Template:USS</a> and <a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:USS&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:USS (page does not exist)">Template:USS</a>, have been lost at sea.  Eight Soviet and Russian nuclear submarines have been lost at sea. This includes the <a href="/wiki/Soviet_submarine_K-19" title="Soviet submarine K-19">Soviet submarine K-19</a> reactor accident in 1961 which resulted in 8 deaths and more than 30 other people were over-exposed to radiation.<sup id="cite_ref-rad_18-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-rad-18">[18]</a></sup> The <a href="/wiki/Soviet_submarine_K-27" title="Soviet submarine K-27">Soviet submarine K-27</a> reactor accident in 1968 resulted in 9 fatalities and 83 other injuries.<sup id="cite_ref-johnston2007_19-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-johnston2007-19">[19]</a></sup> Moreover, <a href="/wiki/Soviet_submarine_K-429" title="Soviet submarine K-429">Soviet submarine K-429</a> sank twice, but was raised after each incident. Several <a href="/w/index.php?title=Nuclear_and_radiation_accidents_by_death_toll&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Nuclear and radiation accidents by death toll (page does not exist)">serious nuclear and radiation accidents</a> have involved nuclear submarine mishaps.<sup id="cite_ref-timenuke_17-2" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-timenuke-17">[17]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-johnston2007_19-2" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-johnston2007-19">[19]</a></sup>
</p><p>The <a href="/wiki/United_States_Army" title="United States Army">U.S. Army</a> also had a <a href="/wiki/Army_Nuclear_Power_Program" title="Army Nuclear Power Program">nuclear power program</a>, beginning in 1954. The SM-1 Nuclear Power Plant, at <a href="/w/index.php?title=Fort_Belvoir&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Fort Belvoir (page does not exist)">Fort Belvoir</a>, <a href="/wiki/Virginia" title="Virginia">Virginia</a>, was the first power reactor in the U.S. to supply electrical energy to a commercial grid (VEPCO), in April 1957, before Shippingport.  The <a href="/wiki/SL-1" title="SL-1">SL-1</a> was a U.S. Army experimental <a href="/wiki/Nuclear_reactor" title="Nuclear reactor">nuclear power reactor</a> at the <a href="/wiki/Idaho_National_Laboratory" title="Idaho National Laboratory">National Reactor Testing Station</a> in <a href="/w/index.php?title=Eastern_Idaho&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Eastern Idaho (page does not exist)">eastern</a>  <a href="/wiki/Idaho" title="Idaho">Idaho</a>.  It underwent a <a href="/wiki/Steam_explosion" title="Steam explosion">steam explosion</a> and <a href="/wiki/Nuclear_meltdown" title="Nuclear meltdown">meltdown</a> in January 1961, which killed its three operators.<sup id="cite_ref-68" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-68">[68]</a></sup> In Soviet Union in The <a href="/wiki/Mayak" title="Mayak">Mayak</a> Production Association there were a number of accidents including an explosion that released 50-100 tonnes of high-level radioactive waste, contaminating a huge territory in the eastern Urals and causing numerous deaths and injuries. The Soviet regime kept this accident secret for about 30 years. The event was eventually rated at 6 on the seven-level INES scale (third in severity only to the disasters at Chernobyl and Fukushima).
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Development">Development</span></h3>
<div class="thumb tleft"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:182px;"><a href="/wiki/File:Nuclear_Power_History.png" title="File:Nuclear Power History.png">File:Nuclear Power History.png</a>  <div class="thumbcaption">History of the use of nuclear power (top) and the number of active nuclear power plants (bottom).</div></div></div>
<div class="thumb tleft"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:182px;"><a href="/wiki/File:Satsop_Development_Park_07780.JPG" title="File:Satsop Development Park 07780.JPG">File:Satsop Development Park 07780.JPG</a>  <div class="thumbcaption"><a href="/w/index.php?title=Washington_Public_Power_Supply_System&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Washington Public Power Supply System (page does not exist)">Washington Public Power Supply System</a> Nuclear Power Plants 3 and 5 were never completed.</div></div></div>
<p>Installed nuclear capacity initially rose relatively quickly, rising from less than 1 <a href="/wiki/Gigawatt" title="Gigawatt" class="mw-redirect">gigawatt</a> (GW) in 1960 to 100 GW in the late 1970s, and 300 GW in the late 1980s. Since the late 1980s worldwide capacity has risen much more slowly, reaching 366 GW in 2005. Between around 1970 and 1990, more than 50 GW of capacity was under construction (peaking at over 150 GW in the late 70s and early 80s) — in 2005, around 25 GW of new capacity was planned. More than two-thirds of all nuclear plants ordered after January 1970 were eventually cancelled.<sup id="cite_ref-iaeapdf_67-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-iaeapdf-67">[67]</a></sup> A total of <a href="/w/index.php?title=List_of_canceled_nuclear_plants_in_the_United_States&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="List of canceled nuclear plants in the United States (page does not exist)">63 nuclear units were canceled</a> in the USA between 1975 and 1980.<sup id="cite_ref-69" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-69">[69]</a></sup>
</p><p>During the 1970s and 1980s rising economic costs (related to extended construction times largely due to regulatory changes and pressure-group litigation)<sup id="cite_ref-70" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-70">[70]</a></sup> and falling fossil fuel prices made nuclear power plants then under construction less attractive. In the 1980s (U.S.) and 1990s (Europe), flat load growth and <a href="/wiki/Electricity_liberalization" title="Electricity liberalization">electricity liberalization</a> also made the addition of large new baseload capacity unattractive.
</p><p>The <a href="/wiki/1973_oil_crisis" title="1973 oil crisis">1973 oil crisis</a> had a significant effect on countries, such as France and Japan, which had relied more heavily on oil for electric generation (39%<sup id="cite_ref-71" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-71">[71]</a></sup> and 73% respectively) to invest in nuclear power.<sup id="cite_ref-72" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-72">[72]</a></sup>
</p>
Some local opposition to nuclear power emerged in the early 1960s,<sup id="cite_ref-well_73-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-well-73">[73]</a></sup> and in the late 1960s some members of the scientific community began to express their concerns.<sup id="cite_ref-wolfgang_74-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-wolfgang-74">[74]</a></sup> These concerns related to <a href="/wiki/Nuclear_accident" title="Nuclear accident" class="mw-redirect">nuclear accidents</a>, <a href="/wiki/Nuclear_proliferation" title="Nuclear proliferation">nuclear proliferation</a>, <a href="/w/index.php?title=Economics_of_new_nuclear_power_plants&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Economics of new nuclear power plants (page does not exist)">high cost of nuclear power plants</a>, <a href="/wiki/Nuclear_terrorism" title="Nuclear terrorism">nuclear terrorism</a> and <a href="/w/index.php?title=Radioactive_waste_disposal&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Radioactive waste disposal (page does not exist)">radioactive waste disposal</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-bm_75-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-bm-75">[75]</a></sup> In the early 1970s, there were large protests about a proposed nuclear power plant in <a href="/w/index.php?title=Wyhl&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Wyhl (page does not exist)">Wyhl</a>, Germany. The project was cancelled in 1975 and anti-nuclear success at Wyhl inspired opposition to nuclear power in other parts of Europe and North America.<sup id="cite_ref-pub_76-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-pub-76">[76]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-got_77-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-got-77">[77]</a></sup> By the mid-1970s anti-nuclear activism had moved beyond local protests and politics to gain a wider appeal and influence, and nuclear power became an issue of major public protest.<sup id="cite_ref-jimfalk_78-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-jimfalk-78">[78]</a></sup> Although it lacked a single co-ordinating organization, and did not have uniform goals, the movement's efforts gained a great deal of attention.<sup id="cite_ref-eleven_79-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-eleven-79">[79]</a></sup> In some countries, the <a href="/w/index.php?title=Nuclear_power_debate&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Nuclear power debate (page does not exist)">nuclear power conflict</a> "reached an intensity unprecedented in the history of technology controversies".<sup id="cite_ref-marcuse.org_80-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-marcuse.org-80">[80]</a></sup> <div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:182px;"><a href="/wiki/File:ANTIAKW.jpg" title="File:ANTIAKW.jpg">File:ANTIAKW.jpg</a>  <div class="thumbcaption">120,000 people attended an <a href="/w/index.php?title=Anti-nuclear_protest&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Anti-nuclear protest (page does not exist)">anti-nuclear protest</a> in <a href="/wiki/Bonn" title="Bonn">Bonn</a>, Germany, on October 14, 1979, following the <a href="/wiki/Three_Mile_Island_accident" title="Three Mile Island accident">Three Mile Island accident</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-kits_81-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-kits-81">[81]</a></sup></div></div></div>
<p>In France, between 1975 and 1977, some 175,000 people protested against nuclear power in ten demonstrations.<sup id="cite_ref-kits_81-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-kits-81">[81]</a></sup> In West Germany, between February 1975 and April 1979, some 280,000 people were involved in seven demonstrations at nuclear sites. Several site occupations were also attempted. In the aftermath of the <a href="/wiki/Three_Mile_Island_accident" title="Three Mile Island accident">Three Mile Island accident</a> in 1979, some 120,000 people attended a demonstration against nuclear power in <a href="/wiki/Bonn" title="Bonn">Bonn</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-kits_81-2" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-kits-81">[81]</a></sup> In May 1979, an estimated 70,000 people, including then governor of California <a href="/wiki/Jerry_Brown" title="Jerry Brown">Jerry Brown</a>, attended a march and rally against nuclear power in Washington, D.C.<sup id="cite_ref-diablo_82-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-diablo-82">[82]</a></sup> <a href="/w/index.php?title=List_of_anti-nuclear_power_groups&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="List of anti-nuclear power groups (page does not exist)">Anti-nuclear power groups</a> emerged in every country that has had a nuclear power programme. Some of these anti-nuclear power organisations are reported to have developed considerable expertise on nuclear power and energy issues.<sup id="cite_ref-schneider_83-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-schneider-83">[83]</a></sup>
</p>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:182px;"><a href="/wiki/File:View_of_Chernobyl_taken_from_Pripyat.JPG" title="File:View of Chernobyl taken from Pripyat.JPG">File:View of Chernobyl taken from Pripyat.JPG</a>  <div class="thumbcaption">The abandoned city of <a href="/w/index.php?title=Pripyat_(city)&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Pripyat (city) (page does not exist)">Pripyat</a> with Chernobyl plant in the distance.</div></div></div>
<p>Health and safety concerns, the 1979 accident at <a href="/wiki/Three_Mile_Island_accident" title="Three Mile Island accident">Three Mile Island</a>, and the 1986 <a href="/w/index.php?title=Chernobyl_disaster&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Chernobyl disaster (page does not exist)">Chernobyl disaster</a> played a part in stopping new plant construction in many countries,<sup id="cite_ref-wolfgang_74-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-wolfgang-74">[74]</a></sup> although the public policy organization, the <a href="/wiki/Brookings_Institution" title="Brookings Institution">Brookings Institution</a> states that new nuclear units, at the time of publishing in 2006, had not been built in the U.S. because of soft demand for electricity, and cost overruns on nuclear plants due to regulatory issues and construction delays.<sup id="cite_ref-tbi_84-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-tbi-84">[84]</a></sup> By the end of the 1970s it became clear that nuclear power would not grow nearly as dramatically as once believed.  Eventually, more than 120 reactor orders in the U.S. were ultimately cancelled<sup id="cite_ref-85" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-85">[85]</a></sup> and the construction of new reactors ground to a halt. A cover story in the February 11, 1985, issue of <i><a href="/wiki/Forbes_magazine" title="Forbes magazine" class="mw-redirect">Forbes magazine</a></i> commented on the overall failure of the U.S. nuclear power program, saying it “ranks as the largest managerial disaster in business history”.<sup id="cite_ref-ReferenceA_86-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-ReferenceA-86">[86]</a></sup>
</p><p>Unlike the Three Mile Island accident, the much more serious Chernobyl accident did not increase regulations affecting Western reactors since the Chernobyl reactors were of the problematic <a href="/wiki/RBMK" title="RBMK">RBMK</a> design only used in the Soviet Union, for example lacking "robust" <a href="/wiki/Containment_building" title="Containment building">containment buildings</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-NRC_87-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-NRC-87">[87]</a></sup> Many of these RBMK reactors are still in use today. However, changes were made in both the reactors themselves (use of a safer enrichment of uranium) and in the control system (prevention of disabling safety systems), amongst other things, to reduce the possibility of a duplicate accident.<sup id="cite_ref-88" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-88">[88]</a></sup>
</p><p>An international organization to promote safety awareness and professional development on operators in nuclear facilities was created: <a href="/w/index.php?title=World_Association_of_Nuclear_Operators&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="World Association of Nuclear Operators (page does not exist)">WANO</a>; World Association of Nuclear Operators.
</p><p>Opposition in Ireland and Poland prevented nuclear programs there, while Austria (1978), Sweden (1980) and Italy (1987) (influenced by Chernobyl) voted in referendums to oppose or phase out nuclear power. In July 2009, the Italian Parliament passed a law that cancelled the results of an earlier referendum and allowed the immediate start of the Italian nuclear program.<sup id="cite_ref-89" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-89">[89]</a></sup> After the <a href="/w/index.php?title=Fukushima_Daiichi_nuclear_disaster&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Fukushima Daiichi nuclear disaster (page does not exist)">Fukushima Daiichi nuclear disaster</a> a one year moratorium was placed on nuclear power development,<sup id="cite_ref-90" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-90">[90]</a></sup> followed by a referendum in which over 94% of voters (turnout 57%) rejected plans for new nuclear power.<sup id="cite_ref-91" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-91">[91]</a></sup>
</p>
<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="Nuclear_power_plant">Nuclear power plant</span></h2>
<div class="thumb tleft"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:182px;"><a href="/wiki/File:PWR_nuclear_power_plant_animation.ogv" title="File:PWR nuclear power plant animation.ogv">File:PWR nuclear power plant animation.ogv</a>  <div class="thumbcaption">An animation of a <a href="/wiki/Pressurized_water_reactor" title="Pressurized water reactor">Pressurized water reactor</a> in operation.</div></div></div>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:182px;"><a href="/wiki/File:Nuclear_Power_Plant_Cattenom_a.png" title="File:Nuclear Power Plant Cattenom a.png">File:Nuclear Power Plant Cattenom a.png</a>  <div class="thumbcaption">Unlike <a href="/wiki/Fossil-fuel_power_station" title="Fossil-fuel power station">fossil fuel power plants</a>, the only substance leaving the cooling towers of <a href="/wiki/Nuclear_power_plants" title="Nuclear power plants" class="mw-redirect">nuclear power plants</a> is water vapour and thus does not <a href="/w/index.php?title=Air_pollution&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Air pollution (page does not exist)">pollute the air</a> or cause <a href="/w/index.php?title=Global_warming&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Global warming (page does not exist)">global warming</a>.</div></div></div>
<p><a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Rellink&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Rellink (page does not exist)">Template:Rellink</a>
Just as many conventional <a href="/w/index.php?title=Thermal_power_station&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Thermal power station (page does not exist)">thermal power stations</a> generate electricity by harnessing the <a href="/wiki/Thermal_energy" title="Thermal energy">thermal energy</a> released from burning <a href="/wiki/Fossil_fuels" title="Fossil fuels" class="mw-redirect">fossil fuels</a>, nuclear power plants convert the energy released from the nucleus of an atom via <a href="/wiki/Nuclear_fission" title="Nuclear fission">nuclear fission</a> that takes place in a <a href="/wiki/Nuclear_reactor" title="Nuclear reactor">nuclear reactor</a>. The heat is removed from the reactor core by a cooling system that uses the heat to generate steam, which drives a <a href="/wiki/Steam_turbine" title="Steam turbine">steam turbine</a> connected to a <a href="/w/index.php?title=Electrical_generator&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Electrical generator (page does not exist)">generator</a> producing <a href="/wiki/Electricity" title="Electricity">electricity</a>.
</p>
<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="Life_cycle">Life cycle</span></h2>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:182px;"><a href="/wiki/File:Nuclear_Fuel_Cycle.png" title="File:Nuclear Fuel Cycle.png">File:Nuclear Fuel Cycle.png</a>  <div class="thumbcaption">The nuclear fuel cycle begins when uranium is mined, enriched, and manufactured into nuclear fuel, (1) which is delivered to a <a href="/wiki/Nuclear_power_plant" title="Nuclear power plant">nuclear power plant</a>. After usage in the power plant, the spent fuel is delivered to a reprocessing plant (2) or to a final repository (3) for geological disposition. In <a href="/wiki/Nuclear_reprocessing" title="Nuclear reprocessing">reprocessing</a> 95% of spent fuel can potentially be recycled to be returned to usage in a power plant (4).</div></div></div>
<p><a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Rellink&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Rellink (page does not exist)">Template:Rellink</a>
</p><p>A nuclear reactor is only part of the life-cycle for nuclear power. The process starts with mining (see <i><a href="/w/index.php?title=Uranium_mining&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Uranium mining (page does not exist)">Uranium mining</a></i>). Uranium mines are underground, <a href="/wiki/Open-pit_mining" title="Open-pit mining">open-pit</a>, or <a href="/w/index.php?title=In-situ_leach&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="In-situ leach (page does not exist)">in-situ leach</a> mines. In any case, the uranium ore is extracted, usually converted into a stable and compact form such as <a href="/wiki/Yellowcake" title="Yellowcake">yellowcake</a>, and then transported to a processing facility. Here, the yellowcake is converted to <a href="/wiki/Uranium_hexafluoride" title="Uranium hexafluoride">uranium hexafluoride</a>, which is then <a href="/wiki/Uranium_enrichment" title="Uranium enrichment" class="mw-redirect">enriched</a> using various techniques. At this point, the enriched uranium, containing more than the natural 0.7% U-235, is used to make <a href="/wiki/Fuel_rod#Common_physical_forms_of_nuclear_fuel" title="Fuel rod" class="mw-redirect">rods</a> of the proper composition and geometry for the particular reactor that the fuel is destined for. The fuel rods will spend about 3 operational cycles (typically 6 years total now) inside the reactor, generally until about 3% of their uranium has been fissioned, then they will be moved to a <a href="/w/index.php?title=Spent_fuel_pool&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Spent fuel pool (page does not exist)">spent fuel pool</a> where the short lived isotopes generated by fission can decay away. After about 5 years in a spent fuel pool the spent fuel is radioactively and thermally cool enough to handle, and it can be moved to dry storage casks or reprocessed.
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Conventional_fuel_resources">Conventional fuel resources</span></h3>
<p><a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Rellink&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Rellink (page does not exist)">Template:Rellink</a>
</p>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:182px;"><a href="/wiki/File:Uranium_enrichment_proportions.svg" title="File:Uranium enrichment proportions.svg">File:Uranium enrichment proportions.svg</a>  <div class="thumbcaption">Proportions of the isotopes, <a href="/wiki/Uranium-238" title="Uranium-238">uranium-238</a> (blue) and uranium-235 (red) found naturally, versus grades that are <a href="/w/index.php?title=Enriched_Uranium&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Enriched Uranium (page does not exist)">enriched</a>. <a href="/wiki/Light_water_reactor" title="Light water reactor">light water reactors</a> require fuel enriched to (3-4%), while others such as the <a href="/wiki/CANDU" title="CANDU" class="mw-redirect">CANDU</a> reactor uses natural uranium.</div></div></div>
<p><a href="/wiki/Uranium" title="Uranium">Uranium</a> is a fairly common <a href="/wiki/Chemical_element" title="Chemical element">element</a> in the Earth's crust. Uranium is approximately as common as <a href="/wiki/Tin" title="Tin">tin</a> or <a href="/wiki/Germanium" title="Germanium">germanium</a> in the Earth's crust, and is about 40&#160;times more common than <a href="/wiki/Silver" title="Silver">silver</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-92" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-92">[92]</a></sup> Uranium is a constituent of most rocks, dirt, and of the oceans. The fact that uranium is so spread out is a problem because mining uranium is only economically feasible where there is a large concentration. Still, the world's present measured resources of uranium, economically recoverable at a price of 130&#160;USD/kg, are enough to last for between 70 and 100 years.<sup id="cite_ref-93" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-93">[93]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-94" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-94">[94]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-Red_95-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Red-95">[95]</a></sup> Uranium represents a higher level of assured resources than is normal for most minerals. On the basis of analogies with other metallic minerals, a doubling of price from present levels could be expected to create about a tenfold increase in measured resources, over time.
</p>
According to the <a href="/wiki/OECD" title="OECD" class="mw-redirect">OECD</a> in 2006, there is an expected 85 years worth of uranium in identified resources, when that uranium is used in <a href="/wiki/Light_water_reactor" title="Light water reactor">present reactor technology</a>, with 670 years of economically recoverable uranium in total conventional resources and <a href="/wiki/Phosphate" title="Phosphate">phosphate</a> ores, while also using <a href="/wiki/Light_water_reactor" title="Light water reactor">present reactor technology</a>, a resource that is recoverable from between 60-100 US$/kg of Uranium.<sup id="cite_ref-96" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-96">[96]</a></sup> The <a href="/wiki/OECD" title="OECD" class="mw-redirect">OECD</a> have noted  that: <blockquote class="templatequote">Even if the nuclear industry expands significantly, sufficient fuel is available for centuries. If advanced <a href="/wiki/Breeder_reactor" title="Breeder reactor">breeder reactors</a> could be designed in the future to efficiently utilize recycled or depleted uranium and all actinides, then the resource utilization efficiency would be further improved by an additional factor of eight.
</blockquote> For example, the <a href="/wiki/OECD" title="OECD" class="mw-redirect">OECD</a> have determined that with a pure <a href="/wiki/Fast_reactor" title="Fast reactor" class="mw-redirect">fast reactor</a> fuel cycle with a burn up of, and recycling of, all the Uranium and <a href="/wiki/Actinides" title="Actinides" class="mw-redirect">actinides</a>, actinides which presently make up the most hazardous substances in <a href="/wiki/Nuclear_waste" title="Nuclear waste" class="mw-redirect">nuclear waste</a>, there is 160,000 years worth of Uranium in total conventional resources and <a href="/wiki/Phosphate" title="Phosphate">phosphate</a> ore.<sup id="cite_ref-97" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-97">[97]</a></sup>
<p>According to the <a href="/wiki/OECD" title="OECD" class="mw-redirect">OECD</a>'s red book in 2011, due to increased exploration, known uranium resources have grown by 12.5% since 2008, with this increase translating into greater than a century of uranium available if the metals usage rate were to continue at the 2011 level.<sup id="cite_ref-98" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-98">[98]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-99" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-99">[99]</a></sup>
</p><p>Current <a href="/wiki/Light_water_reactor" title="Light water reactor">light water reactors</a> make relatively inefficient use of nuclear fuel, fissioning only the very rare uranium-235 isotope. <a href="/wiki/Nuclear_reprocessing" title="Nuclear reprocessing">Nuclear reprocessing</a> can make this waste reusable, and more efficient reactor designs, such as the currently under construction <a href="/w/index.php?title=Generation_III_reactor&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Generation III reactor (page does not exist)">Generation III reactors</a> achieve a higher efficiency burn up of the available resources, than the current vintage <a href="/w/index.php?title=Generation_II_reactor&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Generation II reactor (page does not exist)">generation II reactors</a>, which make up the vast majority of reactors worldwide.<sup id="cite_ref-wna-wmitnfc_100-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-wna-wmitnfc-100">[100]</a></sup>
</p>
<h4><span class="mw-headline" id="Breeding">Breeding</span></h4>
<p><a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Rellink&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Rellink (page does not exist)">Template:Rellink</a>
</p><p>As opposed to current light water reactors which use uranium-235 (0.7% of all natural uranium), fast breeder reactors use uranium-238 (99.3% of all natural uranium). It has been estimated that there is up to five billion years' worth of uranium-238 for use in these power plants.<sup id="cite_ref-stanford-cohen_101-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-stanford-cohen-101">[101]</a></sup>
</p><p>Breeder technology has been used in several reactors, but the high cost of reprocessing fuel safely, at 2006 technological levels, requires uranium prices of more than 200 USD/kg before becoming justified economically.<sup id="cite_ref-wna-anpr_102-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-wna-anpr-102">[102]</a></sup> Breeder reactors are still however being pursued as they have the potential to burn up all of the <a href="/wiki/Actinide" title="Actinide">actinides</a> in the present inventory of nuclear waste while also producing power and creating additional quantities of fuel for more reactors via the breeding process.<sup id="cite_ref-103" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-103">[103]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-104" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-104">[104]</a></sup> In 2005, there were two breeder reactors producing power: the <a href="/wiki/Ph%C3%A9nix" title="Phénix">Phénix</a> in France, which has since powered down in 2009 after 36 years of operation, and the <a href="/w/index.php?title=BN-600_reactor&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="BN-600 reactor (page does not exist)">BN-600 reactor</a>, a reactor constructed in 1980 Beloyarsk, Russia which is still operational as of 2013. The electricity output of BN-600 is 600 MW — Russia plans to expand the nations use of breeder reactors with the <a href="/w/index.php?title=BN-800_reactor&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="BN-800 reactor (page does not exist)">BN-800 reactor</a>, scheduled to become operational in 2014,<sup id="cite_ref-105" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-105">[105]</a></sup> and the technical design of a yet larger breeder, the <a href="/w/index.php?title=BN-1200_reactor&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="BN-1200 reactor (page does not exist)">BN-1200 reactor</a> scheduled to be finalized in 2013, with construction slated for 2015.<sup id="cite_ref-106" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-106">[106]</a></sup> Japan's <a href="/wiki/Monju_Nuclear_Power_Plant" title="Monju Nuclear Power Plant">Monju</a> breeder reactor restarted (having been shut down in 1995) in 2010 for 3 months, but shut down again after equipment fell into the reactor during reactor checkups, it is planned to become re-operational in late 2013.<sup id="cite_ref-107" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-107">[107]</a></sup> Both China and India are building breeder reactors. With the Indian 500 MWe <a href="/w/index.php?title=Prototype_Fast_Breeder_Reactor&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Prototype Fast Breeder Reactor (page does not exist)">Prototype Fast Breeder Reactor</a> scheduled to become operational in 2014, with plans to build five more by 2020.<sup id="cite_ref-108" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-108">[108]</a></sup> The <a href="/w/index.php?title=China_Experimental_Fast_Reactor&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="China Experimental Fast Reactor (page does not exist)">China Experimental Fast Reactor</a> began producing power in 2011.<sup id="cite_ref-109" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-109">[109]</a></sup>
</p><p>Another alternative to fast breeders is thermal breeder reactors that use uranium-233 bred from <a href="/wiki/Thorium" title="Thorium">thorium</a> as fission fuel in the <a href="/w/index.php?title=Thorium_fuel_cycle&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Thorium fuel cycle (page does not exist)">thorium fuel cycle</a>. Thorium is about 3.5 times more common than uranium in the Earth's crust, and has different geographic characteristics. This would extend the total practical fissionable resource base by 450%.<sup id="cite_ref-wna-thorium_110-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-wna-thorium-110">[110]</a></sup> <a href="/w/index.php?title=India%27s_three-stage_nuclear_power_programme&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="India's three-stage nuclear power programme (page does not exist)">India's three-stage nuclear power programme</a> features the use of a <a href="/w/index.php?title=Thorium_fuel_cycle&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Thorium fuel cycle (page does not exist)">thorium fuel cycle</a> in the third stage, as it has abundant thorium reserves but little uranium.
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Solid_waste">Solid waste</span></h3>
<p><a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Rellink&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Rellink (page does not exist)">Template:Rellink</a>
<a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Rellink&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Rellink (page does not exist)">Template:Rellink</a>
</p><p>The most important waste stream from nuclear power plants is <a href="/w/index.php?title=Spent_nuclear_fuel&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Spent nuclear fuel (page does not exist)">spent nuclear fuel</a>. It is primarily composed of unconverted uranium as well as significant quantities of transuranic <a href="/wiki/Actinides" title="Actinides" class="mw-redirect">actinides</a> (plutonium and <a href="/wiki/Curium" title="Curium">curium</a>, mostly). In addition, about 3% of it is fission products from nuclear reactions. The actinides (uranium, plutonium, and curium) are responsible for the bulk of the long-term radioactivity, whereas the fission products are responsible for the bulk of the short-term radioactivity.<sup id="cite_ref-111" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-111">[111]</a></sup>
</p>
<h4><span class="mw-headline" id="High-level_radioactive_waste">High-level radioactive waste</span></h4>
<p><a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Rellink&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Rellink (page does not exist)">Template:Rellink</a>
</p>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:182px;"><a href="/wiki/File:RIAN_archive_132603_Nuclear_power_reactor_fuel_assembly.jpg" title="File:RIAN archive 132603 Nuclear power reactor fuel assembly.jpg">File:RIAN archive 132603 Nuclear power reactor fuel assembly.jpg</a>  <div class="thumbcaption">A <a href="/w/index.php?title=Nuclear_fuel_rod&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Nuclear fuel rod (page does not exist)">nuclear fuel rod</a> assembly bundle being inspected before entering a reactor.</div></div></div>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:182px;"><a href="/wiki/File:Nuclear_dry_storage.jpg" title="File:Nuclear dry storage.jpg">File:Nuclear dry storage.jpg</a>  <div class="thumbcaption">Following interim storage in a <a href="/w/index.php?title=Spent_fuel_pool&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Spent fuel pool (page does not exist)">spent fuel pool</a>, the bundles of used fuel assemblies of a typical nuclear power station are often stored on site in the likes of the eight <a href="/wiki/Dry_cask_storage" title="Dry cask storage">dry cask storage</a> vessels pictured above.<sup id="cite_ref-112" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-112">[112]</a></sup> At <a href="/w/index.php?title=Yankee_Rowe_Nuclear_Power_Station&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Yankee Rowe Nuclear Power Station (page does not exist)">Yankee Rowe Nuclear Power Station</a>, which generated 44 billion <a href="/w/index.php?title=Kilowatt_hours&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Kilowatt hours (page does not exist)">kilowatt hours</a> of electricity over its lifetime, its complete spent fuel inventory is contained within sixteen casks.<sup id="cite_ref-113" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-113">[113]</a></sup></div></div></div>
<p>High-level radioactive waste management concerns management and disposal of highly <a href="/wiki/Radioactive_decay" title="Radioactive decay">radioactive</a> materials created during production of nuclear power. The technical issues in accomplishing this are daunting, due to the extremely long periods <a href="/wiki/Radioactive_waste" title="Radioactive waste">radioactive wastes</a> remain deadly to living organisms. Of particular concern are two <a href="/w/index.php?title=Long-lived_fission_product&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Long-lived fission product (page does not exist)">long-lived fission products</a>, <a href="/w/index.php?title=Technetium-99&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Technetium-99 (page does not exist)">Technetium-99</a> (half-life 220,000 years) and <a href="/w/index.php?title=Iodine-129&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Iodine-129 (page does not exist)">Iodine-129</a> (half-life 15.7 million years),<sup id="cite_ref-114" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-114">[114]</a></sup> which dominate spent nuclear fuel radioactivity after a few thousand years.
