The most troublesome <a href="/wiki/Transuranium_element" title="Transuranium element">transuranic elements</a> in spent fuel are <a href="/w/index.php?title=Isotopes_of_neptunium&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Isotopes of neptunium (page does not exist)">Neptunium-237</a> (half-life two million years) and <a href="/w/index.php?title=Plutonium-239&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Plutonium-239 (page does not exist)">Plutonium-239</a> (half-life 24,000 years).<sup id="cite_ref-115" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-115">[115]</a></sup> Consequently, high-level radioactive waste requires sophisticated treatment and management to successfully isolate it from the <a href="/wiki/Biosphere" title="Biosphere">biosphere</a>. This usually necessitates treatment, followed by a long-term management strategy involving permanent storage, disposal or transformation of the waste into a non-toxic form.<sup id="cite_ref-116" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-116">[116]</a></sup>
</p><p>Governments around the world are considering a range of waste management and disposal options, usually involving deep-geologic placement, although there has been limited progress toward implementing long-term waste management solutions.<sup id="cite_ref-117" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-117">[117]</a></sup> This is partly because the timeframes in question when dealing with <a href="/wiki/Radioactive_waste" title="Radioactive waste">radioactive waste</a> range from 10,000 to millions of years,<sup id="cite_ref-118" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-118">[118]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-119" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-119">[119]</a></sup> according to studies based on the effect of estimated radiation doses.<sup id="cite_ref-120" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-120">[120]</a></sup>
</p><p>Some proposed nuclear reactor designs however such as the American <a href="/w/index.php?title=Integral_Fast_Reactor&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Integral Fast Reactor (page does not exist)">Integral Fast Reactor</a> and the <a href="/wiki/Molten_salt_reactor" title="Molten salt reactor">Molten salt reactor</a> can use the nuclear waste from light water reactors as a fuel, transmutating it to isotopes that would be safe after hundreds, instead of tens of thousands of years. This offers a potentially more attractive alternative to deep geological disposal.<sup id="cite_ref-121" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-121">[121]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-122" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-122">[122]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-123" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-123">[123]</a></sup>
</p><p>Another possibility is the use of <a href="/wiki/Thorium" title="Thorium">thorium</a> in a reactor especially designed for thorium (rather than mixing in thorium with uranium and plutonium (i.e. in existing reactors). <a href="/w/index.php?title=Thorium_fuel_cycle&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Thorium fuel cycle (page does not exist)">Used thorium fuel</a> remains only a few hundreds of years radioactive, instead of tens of thousands of years.<sup id="cite_ref-124" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-124">[124]</a></sup>
</p><p>Since the fraction of a radioisotope's atoms decaying per unit of time is inversely proportional to its half-life, the relative radioactivity of a quantity of buried human <a href="/wiki/Radioactive_waste" title="Radioactive waste">radioactive waste</a> would diminish over time compared to natural radioisotopes (such as the decay chains of 120 trillion tons of thorium and 40 trillion tons of uranium which are <a href="/w/index.php?title=Abundance_of_elements_in_Earth%27s_crust&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Abundance of elements in Earth's crust (page does not exist)">at relatively trace concentrations of parts per million each</a> over the crust's 3 * 10<sup>19</sup> ton mass).<sup id="cite_ref-125" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-125">[125]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-126" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-126">[126]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-127" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-127">[127]</a></sup> For instance, over a timeframe of thousands of years, after the most active short half-life radioisotopes decayed, burying U.S. nuclear waste would increase the radioactivity in the top 2000 feet of rock and soil in the <a href="/w/index.php?title=United_States&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="United States (page does not exist)">United States</a> (10 million km<sup>2</sup>) by <a href="/wiki/Approximation#Mathematics" title="Approximation">≈</a> 1 part in 10 million over the cumulative amount of <a href="/w/index.php?title=Natural_radioactivity&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Natural radioactivity (page does not exist)">natural radioisotopes</a> in such a volume, although the vicinity of the site would have a far higher concentration of artificial radioisotopes underground than such an average.<sup id="cite_ref-128" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-128">[128]</a></sup>
</p>
<h4><span class="mw-headline" id="Low-level_radioactive_waste">Low-level radioactive waste</span></h4>
<p><a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Rellink&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Rellink (page does not exist)">Template:Rellink</a>
</p><p>The nuclear industry also produces a large volume of low-level radioactive waste in the form of contaminated items like clothing, hand tools, water purifier resins, and (upon decommissioning) the materials of which the reactor itself is built. In the US, the <a href="/wiki/Nuclear_Regulatory_Commission" title="Nuclear Regulatory Commission">Nuclear Regulatory Commission</a> has repeatedly attempted to allow low-level materials to be handled as normal waste: landfilled, recycled into consumer items, etcetera.
</p>
<h4><span class="mw-headline" id="Comparing_radioactive_waste_to_industrial_toxic_waste">Comparing radioactive waste to industrial toxic waste</span></h4>
<p>In countries with nuclear power, radioactive wastes comprise less than 1% of total industrial toxic wastes, much of which remains hazardous for long periods.<sup id="cite_ref-wna-wmitnfc_100-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-wna-wmitnfc-100">[100]</a></sup> Overall, nuclear power produces far less waste material by volume than fossil-fuel based power plants.<sup id="cite_ref-129" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-129">[129]</a></sup> <a href="/wiki/Coal" title="Coal">Coal</a>-burning plants are particularly noted for producing large amounts of toxic and mildly radioactive ash due to concentrating naturally occurring metals and mildly radioactive material from the coal.<sup id="cite_ref-130" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-130">[130]</a></sup> A 2008 report from <a href="/wiki/Oak_Ridge_National_Laboratory" title="Oak Ridge National Laboratory">Oak Ridge National Laboratory</a> concluded that coal power actually results in more radioactivity being released into the environment than nuclear power operation, and that the population <a href="/w/index.php?title=Effective_dose_(radiation_safety)&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Effective dose (radiation safety) (page does not exist)">effective dose</a> equivalent, or dose to the public from radiation from coal plants is 100 times as much as from the ideal operation of nuclear plants.<sup id="cite_ref-colmain_131-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-colmain-131">[131]</a></sup> Indeed, coal ash is much less radioactive than <a href="/w/index.php?title=Spent_nuclear_fuel&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Spent nuclear fuel (page does not exist)">spent nuclear fuel</a> on a weight per weight basis, but coal ash is produced in much higher quantities per unit of energy generated, and this is released directly into the environment as <a href="/wiki/Fly_ash" title="Fly ash">fly ash</a>, whereas nuclear plants use shielding to protect the environment from radioactive materials, for example, in <a href="/wiki/Dry_cask_storage" title="Dry cask storage">dry cask storage</a> vessels.<sup id="cite_ref-cejournal_132-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-cejournal-132">[132]</a></sup>
</p>
<h4><span class="mw-headline" id="Waste_disposal">Waste disposal</span></h4>
<p>Disposal of nuclear waste is often said to be the Achilles' heel of the industry.<sup id="cite_ref-mont2011_133-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-mont2011-133">[133]</a></sup> Presently, waste is mainly stored at individual reactor sites and there are over 430 locations around the world where radioactive material continues to accumulate. Some experts suggest that centralized underground repositories which are well-managed, guarded, and monitored, would be a vast improvement.<sup id="cite_ref-mont2011_133-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-mont2011-133">[133]</a></sup> There is an "international consensus on the advisability of storing nuclear waste in <a href="/w/index.php?title=Deep_geological_repository&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Deep geological repository (page does not exist)">deep geological repositories</a>",<sup id="cite_ref-go_134-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-go-134">[134]</a></sup> with the lack of movement of nuclear waste in the 2 billion year old <a href="/wiki/Natural_nuclear_fission_reactor" title="Natural nuclear fission reactor">natural nuclear fission reactors</a> in <a href="/wiki/Oklo" title="Oklo">Oklo</a>, <a href="/wiki/Gabon" title="Gabon">Gabon</a> being cited as "a source of essential information today."<sup id="cite_ref-135" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-135">[135]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-136" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-136">[136]</a></sup>
</p><p>As of 2009 there were no commercial scale purpose built underground repositories in operation.<sup id="cite_ref-go_134-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-go-134">[134]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-137" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-137">[137]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-138" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-138">[138]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-139" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-139">[139]</a></sup> The <a href="/wiki/Waste_Isolation_Pilot_Plant" title="Waste Isolation Pilot Plant">Waste Isolation Pilot Plant</a> in <a href="/wiki/New_Mexico" title="New Mexico">New Mexico</a> has been taking nuclear waste since 1999 from production reactors, but as the name suggests is a research and development facility.
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Reprocessing">Reprocessing</span></h3>
<p><a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Rellink&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Rellink (page does not exist)">Template:Rellink</a>
</p><p>Reprocessing can potentially recover up to 95% of the remaining uranium and plutonium in spent nuclear fuel, putting it into new <a href="/wiki/Mixed_oxide_fuel" title="Mixed oxide fuel" class="mw-redirect">mixed oxide fuel</a>. This produces a reduction in long term radioactivity within the remaining waste, since this is largely short-lived fission products, and reduces its volume by over 90%. Reprocessing of civilian fuel from power reactors is currently done in Britain, France and (formerly) Russia, soon will be done in China and perhaps India, and is being done on an expanding scale in Japan. The full potential of reprocessing has not been achieved because it requires <a href="/wiki/Breeder_reactor" title="Breeder reactor">breeder reactors</a>, which are not commercially available. France is generally cited as the most successful reprocessor, but it presently only recycles 28% (by mass) of the yearly fuel use, 7% within France and another 21% in Russia.<sup id="cite_ref-IEEE_Spectrum_140-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-IEEE_Spectrum-140">[140]</a></sup>
</p><p>Reprocessing is not allowed in the U.S.<sup id="cite_ref-141" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-141">[141]</a></sup> The Obama administration has disallowed <a href="/wiki/Nuclear_reprocessing" title="Nuclear reprocessing">reprocessing</a> of nuclear waste, citing <a href="/wiki/Nuclear_proliferation" title="Nuclear proliferation">nuclear proliferation</a> concerns.<sup id="cite_ref-nature.com_142-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-nature.com-142">[142]</a></sup> In the U.S., spent nuclear fuel is currently all treated as waste.<sup id="cite_ref-143" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-143">[143]</a></sup>
</p>
<h4><span class="mw-headline" id="Depleted_uranium">Depleted uranium</span></h4>
<p><a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Rellink&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Rellink (page does not exist)">Template:Rellink</a>
</p><p>Uranium enrichment produces many tons of <a href="/wiki/Depleted_uranium" title="Depleted uranium">depleted uranium</a> (DU) which consists of U-238 with most of the easily fissile U-235 isotope removed. U-238 is a tough metal with several commercial uses—for example, aircraft production, radiation shielding, and armor—as it has a higher density than <a href="/wiki/Lead" title="Lead">lead</a>. Depleted uranium is also controversially used in munitions; DU penetrators (bullets or <a href="/wiki/APFSDS" title="APFSDS" class="mw-redirect">APFSDS</a> tips) "self sharpen", due to uranium's tendency to fracture along shear bands.<sup id="cite_ref-144" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-144">[144]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-145" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-145">[145]</a></sup>
</p>
<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="Economics">Economics</span></h2>
<p><a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Rellink&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Rellink (page does not exist)">Template:Rellink</a>
</p>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:182px;"><a href="/wiki/File:Ikata_Nuclear_Powerplant.JPG" title="File:Ikata Nuclear Powerplant.JPG">File:Ikata Nuclear Powerplant.JPG</a>  <div class="thumbcaption">The <a href="/w/index.php?title=Ikata_Nuclear_Power_Plant&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Ikata Nuclear Power Plant (page does not exist)">Ikata Nuclear Power Plant</a>, a <a href="/wiki/Pressurized_water_reactor" title="Pressurized water reactor">pressurized water reactor</a> that cools by utilizing a secondary coolant <a href="/wiki/Heat_exchanger" title="Heat exchanger">heat exchanger</a> with a large body of water, an alternative cooling approach to large <a href="/w/index.php?title=Cooling_towers&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Cooling towers (page does not exist)">cooling towers</a>.</div></div></div>
<p>The economics of new nuclear power plants is a controversial subject, since there are diverging views on this topic, and multi-billion dollar investments ride on the choice of an energy source. <a href="/wiki/Nuclear_power_plant" title="Nuclear power plant">Nuclear power plants</a> typically have high capital costs for building the plant, but low fuel costs.  Therefore, comparison with other power generation methods is strongly dependent on assumptions about construction timescales and capital financing for nuclear plants as well as the future costs of fossil fuels and renewables as well as for energy storage solutions for intermittent power sources. Cost estimates also need to take into account <a href="/w/index.php?title=Nuclear_decommissioning&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Nuclear decommissioning (page does not exist)">plant decommissioning</a> and <a href="/wiki/Nuclear_waste" title="Nuclear waste" class="mw-redirect">nuclear waste</a> storage costs. On the other hand measures to <a href="/w/index.php?title=Mitigation_of_global_warming&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Mitigation of global warming (page does not exist)">mitigate</a> <a href="/w/index.php?title=Global_warming&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Global warming (page does not exist)">global warming</a>, such as a <a href="/wiki/Carbon_tax" title="Carbon tax">carbon tax</a> or <a href="/wiki/Carbon_emissions_trading" title="Carbon emissions trading" class="mw-redirect">carbon emissions trading</a>, may favor the economics of nuclear power.
</p><p>In recent years there has been a slowdown of electricity demand growth and financing has become more difficult, which has an impact on large projects such as nuclear reactors, with very large upfront costs and long project cycles which carry a large variety of risks.<sup id="cite_ref-kidd2011_146-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-kidd2011-146">[146]</a></sup> In Eastern Europe, a number of long-established projects are struggling to find finance, notably Belene in Bulgaria and the additional reactors at Cernavoda in Romania, and some potential backers have pulled out.<sup id="cite_ref-kidd2011_146-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-kidd2011-146">[146]</a></sup> Where cheap gas is available and its future supply relatively secure, this also poses a major problem for nuclear projects.<sup id="cite_ref-kidd2011_146-2" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-kidd2011-146">[146]</a></sup>
</p><p>Analysis of the economics of nuclear power must take into account who bears the risks of future uncertainties. To date all operating nuclear power plants were developed by <a href="/wiki/Nationalized" title="Nationalized" class="mw-redirect">state-owned</a> or <a href="/w/index.php?title=Regulated_market&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Regulated market (page does not exist)">regulated</a> <a href="/w/index.php?title=Electric_utility&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Electric utility (page does not exist)">utility monopolies</a><sup id="cite_ref-ft-20100912_147-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-ft-20100912-147">[147]</a></sup> where many of the risks associated with construction costs, operating performance, fuel price, accident liability and other factors were borne by consumers rather than suppliers. In addition, because the potential liability from a nuclear accident is so great, the full cost of liability insurance is generally limited/capped by the government, which the <a href="/w/index.php?title=U.S._Nuclear_Regulatory_Commission&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="U.S. Nuclear Regulatory Commission (page does not exist)">U.S. Nuclear Regulatory Commission</a> concluded constituted a significant subsidy.<sup id="cite_ref-148" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-148">[148]</a></sup>  Many countries have now liberalized the <a href="/wiki/Electricity_market" title="Electricity market">electricity market</a> where these risks, and the risk of cheaper competitors emerging before capital costs are recovered, are borne by plant suppliers and operators rather than consumers, which leads to a significantly different evaluation of the economics of new nuclear power plants.<sup id="cite_ref-MIT-2003_149-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-MIT-2003-149">[149]</a></sup>
</p><p>Following the 2011 <a href="/w/index.php?title=Fukushima_Daiichi_nuclear_disaster&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Fukushima Daiichi nuclear disaster (page does not exist)">Fukushima Daiichi nuclear disaster</a>, costs are expected to increase for currently operating and new nuclear power plants, due to increased requirements for on-site spent fuel management and elevated design basis threats.<sup id="cite_ref-150" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-150">[150]</a></sup>
</p>
<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="Accidents_and_safety.2C_the_human_and_financial_costs">Accidents and safety, the human and financial costs</span></h2>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:182px;"><a href="/wiki/File:Fukushima_I_by_Digital_Globe_crop.jpg" title="File:Fukushima I by Digital Globe crop.jpg">File:Fukushima I by Digital Globe crop.jpg</a>  <div class="thumbcaption">The 2011 <a href="/w/index.php?title=Fukushima_Daiichi_nuclear_disaster&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Fukushima Daiichi nuclear disaster (page does not exist)">Fukushima Daiichi nuclear disaster</a>, the world's worst <a href="/wiki/Nuclear_accident" title="Nuclear accident" class="mw-redirect">nuclear accident</a> since 1986, displaced 50,000 households after <a href="/wiki/Radiation" title="Radiation">radiation</a> leaked into the air, soil and sea.<sup id="cite_ref-151" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-151">[151]</a></sup> Radiation checks led to bans of some shipments of vegetables and fish.<sup id="cite_ref-152" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-152">[152]</a></sup></div></div></div>
<p><a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Rellink&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Rellink (page does not exist)">Template:Rellink</a>
</p><p>Some serious <a href="/w/index.php?title=Nuclear_and_radiation_accidents_by_death_toll&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Nuclear and radiation accidents by death toll (page does not exist)">nuclear and radiation accidents</a> have occurred. <a href="/w/index.php?title=Benjamin_K._Sovacool&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Benjamin K. Sovacool (page does not exist)">Benjamin K. Sovacool</a> has reported that worldwide there have been 99 accidents at nuclear power plants.<sup id="cite_ref-critev_153-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-critev-153">[153]</a></sup> Fifty-seven accidents have occurred since the Chernobyl disaster, and 57% (56 out of 99) of all nuclear-related accidents have occurred in the USA.<sup id="cite_ref-critev_153-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-critev-153">[153]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-bksaccident_154-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-bksaccident-154">[154]</a></sup>
</p><p><a href="/wiki/Nuclear_power_plant" title="Nuclear power plant">Nuclear power plant</a> accidents include the <a href="/w/index.php?title=Chernobyl_accident&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Chernobyl accident (page does not exist)">Chernobyl accident</a> (1986) with approximately 60 deaths so far attributed to the accident and a predicted, eventual total death toll, of from 4000 to 25,000 latent cancers deaths. The Fukushima Daiichi nuclear disaster (2011), has not caused any radiation related deaths, with a predicted, eventual total death toll, of from 0 to 1000, and the <a href="/wiki/Three_Mile_Island_accident" title="Three Mile Island accident">Three Mile Island accident</a> (1979), no <a href="/wiki/Causal" title="Causal" class="mw-redirect">causal</a> deaths, cancer or otherwise, have been found in follow up studies of this accident.<sup id="cite_ref-timenuke_17-3" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-timenuke-17">[17]</a></sup> Nuclear-powered submarine mishaps include the <a href="/wiki/Soviet_submarine_K-19" title="Soviet submarine K-19">K-19</a> reactor accident (1961),<sup id="cite_ref-rad_18-2" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-rad-18">[18]</a></sup> the <a href="/wiki/Soviet_submarine_K-27" title="Soviet submarine K-27">K-27</a> reactor accident (1968),<sup id="cite_ref-johnston2007_19-3" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-johnston2007-19">[19]</a></sup> and the <a href="/w/index.php?title=Soviet_submarine_K-431&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Soviet submarine K-431 (page does not exist)">K-431</a> reactor accident (1985).<sup id="cite_ref-timenuke_17-4" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-timenuke-17">[17]</a></sup> International research is continuing into safety improvements such as <a href="/w/index.php?title=Passively_safe&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Passively safe (page does not exist)">passively safe</a> plants,<sup id="cite_ref-David_Baurac_2002_47-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-David_Baurac_2002-47">[47]</a></sup> and the possible future use of <a href="/wiki/Nuclear_fusion" title="Nuclear fusion">nuclear fusion</a>.
</p><p>In terms of lives lost per unit of energy generated, nuclear power has caused fewer accidental deaths per unit of energy generated than all other major sources of energy generation. Energy produced by <a href="/wiki/Coal" title="Coal">coal</a>, <a href="/wiki/Petroleum" title="Petroleum">petroleum</a>, <a href="/wiki/Natural_gas" title="Natural gas">natural gas</a> and <a href="/wiki/Hydropower" title="Hydropower">hydropower</a> has caused more deaths per unit of energy generated, from <a href="/w/index.php?title=Air_pollution&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Air pollution (page does not exist)">air pollution</a> and <a href="/w/index.php?title=Energy_accidents&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Energy accidents (page does not exist)">energy accidents</a>. This is found in the following comparisons, when the immediate nuclear related deaths from accidents are compared to the immediate deaths from these other energy sources,<sup id="cite_ref-without_the_hot_air_21-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-without_the_hot_air-21">[21]</a></sup> when the latent, or predicted, indirect cancer deaths from nuclear <a href="/w/index.php?title=Energy_accidents&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Energy accidents (page does not exist)">energy accidents</a> are compared to the immediate deaths from the above energy sources,<sup id="cite_ref-theage2006_23-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-theage2006-23">[23]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-tandfonline1_24-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-tandfonline1-24">[24]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-155" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-155">[155]</a></sup> and when the combined immediate and indirect fatalities from nuclear power and all fossil fuels are compared, fatalities resulting from the mining of the necessary natural resources to power generation and to air pollution.<sup id="cite_ref-156" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-156">[156]</a></sup> With these data, the use of nuclear power has been calculated to have prevented a considerable number of fatalities,  by reducing the proportion of energy that would otherwise have been generated by fossil fuels, and is projected to continue to do so.<sup id="cite_ref-autogenerated1_157-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-autogenerated1-157">[157]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-158" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-158">[158]</a></sup>
</p><p>Nuclear power plant accidents, according to <a href="/w/index.php?title=Benjamin_K._Sovacool&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Benjamin K. Sovacool (page does not exist)">Benjamin K. Sovacool</a>, rank first in terms of their economic cost, accounting for 41 percent of all property damage attributed to <a href="/w/index.php?title=Energy_accidents&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Energy accidents (page does not exist)">energy accidents</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-159" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-159">[159]</a></sup> However analysis presented in the international Journal, <i>Human and Ecological Risk Assessment</i> found that coal, oil, <a href="/wiki/Liquid_petroleum_gas" title="Liquid petroleum gas" class="mw-redirect">Liquid petroleum gas</a> and hydro accidents have cost more than nuclear power accidents.<sup id="cite_ref-160" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-160">[160]</a></sup>
</p><p>Following the 2011 Japanese <a href="/w/index.php?title=Fukushima_nuclear_disaster&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Fukushima nuclear disaster (page does not exist)">Fukushima nuclear disaster</a>, authorities shut down the nation's 54 nuclear power plants, but it has been estimated that if Japan had never adopted nuclear power, accidents and pollution from coal or gas plants would have caused more lost years of life.<sup id="cite_ref-161" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-161">[161]</a></sup> As of 2013, the Fukushima site remains <a href="/w/index.php?title=Radiation_effects_from_Fukushima_Daiichi_nuclear_disaster&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Radiation effects from Fukushima Daiichi nuclear disaster (page does not exist)">highly radioactive</a>, with some 160,000 evacuees still living in temporary housing, and some land will be unfarmable for centuries. The difficult <a href="/w/index.php?title=Fukushima_disaster_cleanup&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Fukushima disaster cleanup (page does not exist)">Fukushima disaster cleanup</a> will take 40 or more years, and cost tens of billions of dollars.<sup id="cite_ref-Richard_Schiffman_25-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Richard_Schiffman-25">[25]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-Martin_Fackler_26-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Martin_Fackler-26">[26]</a></sup>
</p><p>Forced evacuation from a nuclear accident may lead to social isolation, anxiety, depression, psychosomatic medical problems, reckless behavior, even suicide. Such was the outcome of the 1986 <a href="/w/index.php?title=Chernobyl_nuclear_disaster&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Chernobyl nuclear disaster (page does not exist)">Chernobyl nuclear disaster</a> in the Ukraine. A comprehensive 2005 study concluded that "the mental health impact of Chernobyl is the largest public health problem unleashed by the accident to date".<sup id="cite_ref-riv12_162-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-riv12-162">[162]</a></sup> <a href="/w/index.php?title=Frank_N._von_Hippel&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Frank N. von Hippel (page does not exist)">Frank N. von Hippel</a>, a U.S. scientist, commented on the 2011 Fukushima nuclear disaster, saying that "fear of ionizing radiation could have long-term psychological effects on a large portion of the population in the contaminated areas".<sup id="cite_ref-Frank_N._von_Hippel_27.E2.80.9336_163-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Frank_N._von_Hippel_27.E2.80.9336-163">[163]</a></sup>
</p>
<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="Nuclear_proliferation">Nuclear proliferation</span></h2>
<p>Many technologies and materials associated with the creation of a nuclear power program have a dual-use capability, in that they can be used to make <a href="/wiki/Nuclear_weapons" title="Nuclear weapons" class="mw-redirect">nuclear weapons</a> if a country chooses to do so. When this happens a nuclear power program can become a route leading to a <a href="/wiki/Nuclear_weapon" title="Nuclear weapon">nuclear weapon</a> or a public annex to a "secret" weapons program. The concern over <a href="/wiki/Nuclear_program_of_Iran" title="Nuclear program of Iran">Iran's nuclear activities</a> is a case in point.<sup id="cite_ref-dfall2009_164-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-dfall2009-164">[164]</a></sup>
</p>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:182px;"><a href="/wiki/File:US_and_USSR_nuclear_stockpiles.svg" title="File:US and USSR nuclear stockpiles.svg">File:US and USSR nuclear stockpiles.svg</a>  <div class="thumbcaption"><a href="/w/index.php?title=United_States&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="United States (page does not exist)">United States</a> and <a href="/wiki/USSR" title="USSR" class="mw-redirect">USSR</a>/<a href="/wiki/Russia" title="Russia">Russian</a> <a href="/wiki/Nuclear_weapons" title="Nuclear weapons" class="mw-redirect">nuclear weapons</a> stockpiles, 1945-2006.The <a href="/w/index.php?title=Megatons_to_Megawatts_Program&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Megatons to Megawatts Program (page does not exist)">Megatons to Megawatts Program</a> was the main driving force behind the sharp reduction in the quantity of nuclear weapons worldwide since the cold war ended.<sup id="cite_ref-thebulletin.org_165-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-thebulletin.org-165">[165]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-usec.com_166-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-usec.com-166">[166]</a></sup> However without an increase in nuclear reactors and greater demand for <a href="/wiki/Fissile" title="Fissile">fissile</a> fuel, the cost of dismantling has dissuaded Russia from continuing their disarmament.</div></div></div>
<p>A fundamental goal for American and global security is to minimize the <a href="/wiki/Nuclear_proliferation" title="Nuclear proliferation">nuclear proliferation</a> risks associated with the expansion of nuclear power. If this development is "poorly managed or efforts to contain risks are unsuccessful, the nuclear future will be dangerous".<sup id="cite_ref-dfall2009_164-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-dfall2009-164">[164]</a></sup> The <a href="/w/index.php?title=Global_Nuclear_Energy_Partnership&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Global Nuclear Energy Partnership (page does not exist)">Global Nuclear Energy Partnership</a> is one such international effort to create a distribution network in which developing countries in need of energy, would receive <a href="/wiki/Nuclear_fuel" title="Nuclear fuel">nuclear fuel</a> at a discounted rate, in exchange for that nation agreeing to forgo their own indigenous develop of a <a href="/wiki/Uranium_enrichment" title="Uranium enrichment" class="mw-redirect">uranium enrichment</a> program.
</p><p>According to <a href="/w/index.php?title=Benjamin_K._Sovacool&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Benjamin K. Sovacool (page does not exist)">Benjamin K. Sovacool</a>, a "number of high-ranking officials, even within the United Nations, have argued that they can do little to stop states using nuclear reactors to produce nuclear weapons".<sup id="cite_ref-bks2011_167-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-bks2011-167">[167]</a></sup> A 2009 United Nations report said that:
</p>
<blockquote>the revival of interest in nuclear power could result in the worldwide dissemination of uranium enrichment and spent fuel reprocessing technologies, which present obvious risks of proliferation as these technologies can produce fissile materials that are directly usable in nuclear weapons.<sup id="cite_ref-bks2011_167-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-bks2011-167">[167]</a></sup>
</blockquote>
<p>On the other hand, one factor influencing the support of power reactors is due to the appeal that these reactors have at reducing nuclear weapons arsenals through the <a href="/w/index.php?title=Megatons_to_Megawatts_Program&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Megatons to Megawatts Program (page does not exist)">Megatons to Megawatts Program</a>, a program which has thus far eliminated 425 metric tons of highly enriched uranium, the equivalent of 17,000 nuclear warheads, by converting it into fuel for commercial nuclear reactors, and it is the single most successful <a href="/w/index.php?title=Non-proliferation&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Non-proliferation (page does not exist)">non-proliferation</a> program to date.<sup id="cite_ref-thebulletin.org_165-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-thebulletin.org-165">[165]</a></sup>
</p>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:182px;"><a href="/wiki/File:Usable_nuclear_energy_in_ICBM.png" title="File:Usable nuclear energy in ICBM.png">File:Usable nuclear energy in ICBM.png</a>  <div class="thumbcaption"></div></div></div>
<p>The <a href="/w/index.php?title=Megatons_to_Megawatts_Program&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Megatons to Megawatts Program (page does not exist)">Megatons to Megawatts Program</a> has been hailed as a major success by anti-nuclear weapon advocates as it has largely been the driving force behind the sharp reduction in the quantity of nuclear weapons worldwide since the cold war ended.<sup id="cite_ref-thebulletin.org_165-2" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-thebulletin.org-165">[165]</a></sup> However without an increase in nuclear reactors and greater demand for fissile fuel, the cost of dismantling and down blending has dissuaded Russia from continuing their disarmament.
</p><p>Currently, according to Harvard professor Matthew Bunn: "The Russians are not remotely interested in extending the program beyond 2013. We've managed to set it up in a way that costs them more and profits them less than them just making new low-enriched uranium for reactors from scratch. But there are other ways to set it up that would be very profitable for them and would also serve some of their strategic interests in boosting their nuclear exports."<sup id="cite_ref-168" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-168">[168]</a></sup>
</p><p>In the <a href="/w/index.php?title=Megatons_to_Megawatts_Program&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Megatons to Megawatts Program (page does not exist)">Megatons to Megawatts Program</a> approximately $8 billion of weapons grade uranium is being converted to reactor grade uranium in the elimination of 10,000 nuclear weapons.<sup id="cite_ref-169" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-169">[169]</a></sup>
</p><p>In April 2012 there were <a href="/w/index.php?title=Nuclear_power_by_country&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Nuclear power by country (page does not exist)">thirty one countries</a> that have civil nuclear power plants.<sup id="cite_ref-170" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-170">[170]</a></sup> In 2013, <a href="/w/index.php?title=Mark_Diesendorf&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Mark Diesendorf (page does not exist)">Mark Diesendorf</a> says that governments of France, India, North Korea, Pakistan, UK, and South Africa have used nuclear power and/or research reactors to assist nuclear weapons development or to contribute to their supplies of nuclear explosives from military reactors.<sup id="cite_ref-diesrev_171-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-diesrev-171">[171]</a></sup>
</p>
<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="Environmental_issues">Environmental issues</span></h2>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:182px;"><a href="/wiki/File:Sovacool_2008_life-cycle_study.png" title="File:Sovacool 2008 life-cycle study.png">File:Sovacool 2008 life-cycle study.png</a>  <div class="thumbcaption">A 2008 <a href="/wiki/Meta_analysis" title="Meta analysis" class="mw-redirect">synthesis</a> of 103 studies, published by Benjamin K. Sovacool, estimated that the value of CO<sub>2</sub> emissions for nuclear power over the lifecycle of a plant was 66.08&#160;g/kW·h. Comparative results for various <a href="/w/index.php?title=Renewable_power&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Renewable power (page does not exist)">renewable power</a> sources were 9–32&#160;g/kW·h.<sup id="cite_ref-sov_172-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-sov-172">[172]</a></sup> A 2012 study by <a href="/wiki/Yale_University" title="Yale University">Yale University</a> arrived at a different value, with the mean value, depending on which Reactor design was analyzed, ranging from 11 to 25&#160;g/kW·h of <a href="/w/index.php?title=Comparisons_of_life-cycle_greenhouse-gas_emissions&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Comparisons of life-cycle greenhouse-gas emissions (page does not exist)">total life cycle</a> nuclear power CO<sub>2</sub> emissions.<sup id="cite_ref-173" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-173">[173]</a></sup></div></div></div>
<p><a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Rellink&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Rellink (page does not exist)">Template:Rellink</a>
</p><p><a href="/w/index.php?title=Life_cycle_analysis&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Life cycle analysis (page does not exist)">Life cycle analysis</a> (LCA) of carbon dioxide emissions show nuclear power as comparable to <a href="/wiki/Renewable_energy" title="Renewable energy">renewable energy</a> sources. Emissions from burning fossil fuels are many times higher.<sup id="cite_ref-sov_172-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-sov-172">[172]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-174" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-174">[174]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-175" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-175">[175]</a></sup>
</p><p>According to the United Nations (<a href="/w/index.php?title=UNSCEAR&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="UNSCEAR (page does not exist)">UNSCEAR</a>), regular nuclear power plant operation including the nuclear fuel cycle causes radioisotope releases into the environment amounting to 0.0002&#160;mSv (milli-<a href="/wiki/Sievert" title="Sievert">Sievert</a>) per year of public exposure as a global average.<sup id="cite_ref-UNSCEAR_GA_176-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-UNSCEAR_GA-176">[176]</a></sup> (Such is small compared to variation in natural <a href="/wiki/Background_radiation" title="Background radiation">background radiation</a>, which averages 2.4&#160;mSv/a globally but frequently varies between 1&#160;mSv/a and 13&#160;mSv/a depending on a person's location as determined by UNSCEAR).<sup id="cite_ref-UNSCEAR_GA_176-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-UNSCEAR_GA-176">[176]</a></sup> As of a 2008 report, the remaining legacy of the worst nuclear power plant accident (Chernobyl) is 0.002&#160;mSv/a in global average exposure (a figure which was 0.04&#160;mSv per person averaged over the entire populace of the Northern Hemisphere in the year of the accident in 1986, although far higher among the most affected local populations and recovery workers).<sup id="cite_ref-UNSCEAR_GA_176-2" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-UNSCEAR_GA-176">[176]</a></sup>
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Climate_change">Climate change</span></h3>
<p><a href="/wiki/Climate_change" title="Climate change">Climate change</a> causing weather extremes such as <a href="/w/index.php?title=Heat_waves&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Heat waves (page does not exist)">heat waves</a>, reduced precipitation levels and <a href="/wiki/Droughts" title="Droughts" class="mw-redirect">droughts</a> can have a significant impact on nuclear energy infrastructure.<sup id="cite_ref-ODI1_177-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-ODI1-177">[177]</a></sup> Seawater is corrosive and so nuclear energy supply is likely to be negatively affected by the fresh <a href="/w/index.php?title=Water_shortage&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Water shortage (page does not exist)">water shortage</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-ODI1_177-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-ODI1-177">[177]</a></sup> This generic problem may become increasingly significant over time.<sup id="cite_ref-ODI1_177-2" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-ODI1-177">[177]</a></sup> This can force nuclear reactors to be shut down, as happened in France during the 2003 and 2006 heat waves. Nuclear power supply was severely diminished by low river ﬂow rates and droughts, which meant rivers had reached the maximum temperatures for cooling reactors.<sup id="cite_ref-ODI1_177-3" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-ODI1-177">[177]</a></sup> During the heat waves, 17 reactors had to limit output or shut down. 77% of French electricity is produced by nuclear power and in 2009 a similar situation created a 8GW shortage and forced the French government to import electricity.<sup id="cite_ref-ODI1_177-4" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-ODI1-177">[177]</a></sup> Other cases have been reported from Germany, where extreme temperatures have reduced nuclear power production 9 times due to high temperatures between 1979 and 2007.<sup id="cite_ref-ODI1_177-5" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-ODI1-177">[177]</a></sup> In particular:
</p>
<ul>
<li> the <a href="/w/index.php?title=Unterweser_Nuclear_Power_Plant&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Unterweser Nuclear Power Plant (page does not exist)">Unterweser nuclear power plant</a> reduced output by 90% between June and September 2003<sup id="cite_ref-ODI1_177-6" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-ODI1-177">[177]</a></sup>
</li>
<li> the <a href="/w/index.php?title=Isar_Nuclear_Power_Plant&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Isar Nuclear Power Plant (page does not exist)">Isar nuclear power plant</a> cut production by 60% for 14 days due to excess river temperatures and low stream ﬂow in the river Isar in 2006<sup id="cite_ref-ODI1_177-7" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-ODI1-177">[177]</a></sup>
</li>
</ul>
<p>Similar events have happened elsewhere in Europe during those same hot summers.<sup id="cite_ref-ODI1_177-8" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-ODI1-177">[177]</a></sup> If <a href="/w/index.php?title=Global_warming&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Global warming (page does not exist)">global warming</a> continues, this disruption is likely to increase.
</p>
<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="Nuclear_decommissioning">Nuclear decommissioning</span></h2>
<p>The price of energy inputs and the environmental costs of every nuclear power plant continue long after the facility has finished generating its last useful electricity. Both nuclear reactors and uranium enrichment facilities must be decommissioned, returning the facility and its parts to a safe enough level to be entrusted for other uses. After a cooling-off period that may last as long as a century, reactors must be dismantled and cut into small pieces to be packed in containers for final disposal. The process is very expensive, time-consuming, dangerous for workers, hazardous to the natural environment, and presents new opportunities for human error, accidents or sabotage.<sup id="cite_ref-sov11_178-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-sov11-178">[178]</a></sup>
</p><p>The total energy required for decommissioning can be as much as 50% more than the energy needed for the original construction. In most cases, the decommissioning process costs between US $300 million to US$5.6 billion. Decommissioning at nuclear sites which have experienced a serious accident are the most expensive and time-consuming. In the U.S. there are 13 reactors that have permanently shut down and are in some phase of decommissioning, and none of them have completed the process.<sup id="cite_ref-sov11_178-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-sov11-178">[178]</a></sup>
</p><p>Current UK plants are expected to exceed £73bn in decommissioning costs.<a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Cite_web&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Cite web (page does not exist)">Template:Cite web</a>
</p>
<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="Debate_on_nuclear_power">Debate on nuclear power</span></h2>
<p><a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Rellink&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Rellink (page does not exist)">Template:Rellink</a>
<a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Rellink&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Rellink (page does not exist)">Template:Rellink</a>
</p><p>The <a href="/w/index.php?title=Nuclear_power_debate&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Nuclear power debate (page does not exist)">nuclear power debate</a> concerns the controversy<sup id="cite_ref-jstor.org_11-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-jstor.org-11">[11]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-A_Reasonable_Bet_on_Nuclear_Power_12-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-A_Reasonable_Bet_on_Nuclear_Power-12">[12]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-eleven_79-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-eleven-79">[79]</a></sup> which has surrounded the deployment and use of <a href="/wiki/Nuclear_reactor" title="Nuclear reactor">nuclear fission reactors</a> to generate <a href="/wiki/Electricity" title="Electricity">electricity</a> from <a href="/wiki/Nuclear_fuel" title="Nuclear fuel">nuclear fuel</a> for civilian purposes.  The debate about nuclear power peaked during the 1970s and 1980s, when it "reached an intensity unprecedented in the history of technology controversies", in some countries.<sup id="cite_ref-marcuse.org_80-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-marcuse.org-80">[80]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-179" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-179">[179]</a></sup>
</p><p>Proponents of nuclear energy contend that nuclear power is a <a href="/wiki/Sustainable_energy" title="Sustainable energy">sustainable energy</a> source that reduces <a href="/w/index.php?title=Carbon_emissions&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Carbon emissions (page does not exist)">carbon emissions</a> and increases <a href="/w/index.php?title=Energy_security&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Energy security (page does not exist)">energy security</a> by decreasing dependence on imported energy sources.<sup id="cite_ref-bloomberg.com_13-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-bloomberg.com-13">[13]</a></sup> Proponents claim that nuclear power produces virtually no conventional air pollution, such as greenhouse gases and smog, in contrast to the chief viable alternative of <a href="/wiki/Fossil-fuel_power_station" title="Fossil-fuel power station">fossil fuel</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-180" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-180">[180]</a></sup> Nuclear power can produce <a href="/w/index.php?title=Base-load&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Base-load (page does not exist)">base-load</a> power unlike many renewables which are <a href="/w/index.php?title=Intermittent_energy_source&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Intermittent energy source (page does not exist)">intermittent energy sources</a> lacking large-scale and cheap ways of storing energy.<sup id="cite_ref-181" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-181">[181]</a></sup> <a href="/wiki/M._King_Hubbert" title="M. King Hubbert">M. King Hubbert</a> saw oil as a resource that would <a href="/wiki/Peak_oil" title="Peak oil">run out</a>, and  proposed nuclear energy as a replacement energy source.<sup id="cite_ref-182" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-182">[182]</a></sup> Proponents claim that the risks of storing waste are small and can be further reduced by using the latest technology in newer reactors, and the operational safety record in the Western world is excellent when compared to the other major kinds of power plants.<sup id="cite_ref-183" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-183">[183]</a></sup>
</p><p>Opponents believe that nuclear power poses many threats to people and the environment.<sup id="cite_ref-Share_14-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Share-14">[14]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-NC_WARN_.C2.BB_Nuclear_Power_15-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-NC_WARN_.C2.BB_Nuclear_Power-15">[15]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-Sturgis_16-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Sturgis-16">[16]</a></sup> These threats include the problems of processing, transport and storage of radioactive <a href="/wiki/Nuclear_waste" title="Nuclear waste" class="mw-redirect">nuclear waste</a>, the risk of <a href="/wiki/Nuclear_proliferation" title="Nuclear proliferation">nuclear weapons proliferation</a> and terrorism, as well as health risks and environmental damage from <a href="/w/index.php?title=Uranium_mining&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Uranium mining (page does not exist)">uranium mining</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-gierec_184-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-gierec-184">[184]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-protest_185-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-protest-185">[185]</a></sup> They also contend that reactors themselves are enormously complex machines where many things can and do go wrong; and there have been serious <a href="/wiki/Nuclear_accidents" title="Nuclear accidents" class="mw-redirect">nuclear accidents</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-bksenpol_186-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-bksenpol-186">[186]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-187" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-187">[187]</a></sup> Critics do not believe that the risks of using nuclear fission as a power source can be fully offset through the development of new <a href="/wiki/Technology" title="Technology">technology</a>. They also argue that when all the energy-intensive stages of the <a href="/w/index.php?title=Nuclear_fuel_chain&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Nuclear fuel chain (page does not exist)">nuclear fuel chain</a> are considered, from uranium mining to <a href="/w/index.php?title=Nuclear_decommissioning&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Nuclear decommissioning (page does not exist)">nuclear decommissioning</a>, nuclear power is neither a low-carbon nor an economical electricity source.<sup id="cite_ref-188" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-188">[188]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-189" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-189">[189]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-markd_190-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-markd-190">[190]</a></sup>
</p><p>Arguments of <a href="/w/index.php?title=Economics_of_new_nuclear_power_plants&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Economics of new nuclear power plants (page does not exist)">economics</a> and <a href="/w/index.php?title=Nuclear_safety&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Nuclear safety (page does not exist)">safety</a> are used by both sides of the debate.
</p>
<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="Comparison_with_renewable_energy">Comparison with renewable energy</span></h2>
<p><a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Rellink&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Rellink (page does not exist)">Template:Rellink</a>
</p><p>As of 2013, the World Nuclear Association has said "There is unprecedented interest in renewable energy, particularly solar and wind energy, which provide electricity without giving rise to any carbon dioxide emission. Harnessing these for electricity depends on the cost and efficiency of the technology, which is constantly improving, thus reducing costs per peak kilowatt".<sup id="cite_ref-191" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-191">[191]</a></sup>
</p><p><a href="/w/index.php?title=Renewable_electricity&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Renewable electricity (page does not exist)">Renewable electricity</a> production, from sources such as <a href="/wiki/Wind_power" title="Wind power">wind power</a> and <a href="/w/index.php?title=Solar_power&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Solar power (page does not exist)">solar power</a>, is sometimes criticized for being intermittent or <a href="/w/index.php?title=Variable_renewable_energy&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Variable renewable energy (page does not exist)">variable</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-Kloor_192-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Kloor-192">[192]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-193" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-193">[193]</a></sup>  However, the <a href="/wiki/International_Energy_Agency" title="International Energy Agency">International Energy Agency</a> concluded that deployment of renewable technologies (RETs), when it increases the diversity of electricity sources, contributes to the flexibility of the system. However, the report also concluded (p.&#160;29): "At high levels of grid penetration by RETs the consequences of unmatched demand and supply can pose challenges for grid management. This characteristic may affect how, and the degree to which, RETs can displace fossil fuels and nuclear capacities in power generation."<sup id="cite_ref-194" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-194">[194]</a></sup>
</p><p>Renewable electricity supply in the 20-50+% range has already been implemented in several European systems, albeit in the context of an integrated European grid system.<sup id="cite_ref-Lovins11_195-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Lovins11-195">[195]</a></sup> In 2012, the share of electricity generated by renewable sources in Germany was 21.9%, compared to 16.0% for nuclear power after Germany shut down 7-8 of its 18 nuclear reactors in 2011.<sup id="cite_ref-196" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-196">[196]</a></sup> In the United Kingdom, the amount of energy produced from renewable energy is expected to exceed that from nuclear power by 2018,<sup id="cite_ref-197" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-197">[197]</a></sup> and Scotland plans to obtain all electricity from renewable energy by 2020.<sup id="cite_ref-198" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-198">[198]</a></sup> The majority of installed renewable energy across the world is in the form of <a href="/wiki/Hydro_power" title="Hydro power" class="mw-redirect">hydro power</a>.
</p><p>The <a href="/w/index.php?title=IPCC&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="IPCC (page does not exist)">IPCC</a> has said that if governments were supportive, and the full complement of <a href="/wiki/Renewable_energy" title="Renewable energy">renewable energy</a> technologies were deployed, renewable energy supply could account for almost 80% of the world's energy use within forty years.<sup id="cite_ref-ipccccc_199-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-ipccccc-199">[199]</a></sup> <a href="/wiki/Rajendra_Pachauri" title="Rajendra Pachauri" class="mw-redirect">Rajendra Pachauri</a>, chairman of the IPCC, said the necessary investment in renewables would cost only about 1% of global GDP annually. This approach could contain greenhouse gas levels to less than 450 parts per million, the safe level beyond which climate change becomes catastrophic and irreversible.<sup id="cite_ref-ipccccc_199-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-ipccccc-199">[199]</a></sup>
</p><p>The <a href="/w/index.php?title=Economics_of_new_nuclear_power_plants&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Economics of new nuclear power plants (page does not exist)">cost of nuclear power</a> has followed an increasing trend whereas the <a href="/w/index.php?title=LCOE&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="LCOE (page does not exist)">cost of electricity</a> is declining for wind power.<sup id="cite_ref-200" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-200">[200]</a></sup> In about 2011, <a href="/wiki/Wind_power" title="Wind power">wind power</a> became as inexpensive as natural gas, and anti-nuclear groups have suggested that in 2010 <a href="/w/index.php?title=Solar_power&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Solar power (page does not exist)">solar power</a> became cheaper than nuclear power.<sup id="cite_ref-201" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-201">[201]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-202" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-202">[202]</a></sup> Data from the <a href="/wiki/Energy_Information_Administration" title="Energy Information Administration">EIA</a> in 2011 estimated that in 2016, solar will have a levelized cost of electricity almost twice that of nuclear (21¢/kWh for solar, 11.39¢/kWh for nuclear), and wind somewhat less (9.7¢/kWh).<sup id="cite_ref-203" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-203">[203]</a></sup> However, the US EIA has also cautioned that levelized costs of intermittent sources such as wind and solar are not directly comparable to costs of “dispatchable” sources (those that can be adjusted to meet demand).<sup id="cite_ref-204" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-204">[204]</a></sup>
</p><p>From a safety stand point, nuclear power, in terms of lives lost per unit of electricity delivered, is comparable to and in some cases, lower than many <a href="/wiki/Renewable_energy" title="Renewable energy">renewable energy</a> sources.<sup id="cite_ref-autogenerated2007_20-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-autogenerated2007-20">[20]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-without_the_hot_air_21-2" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-without_the_hot_air-21">[21]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-Starfelt_205-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Starfelt-205">[205]</a></sup> There is however no radioactive spent fuel that needs to be stored or reprocessed with conventional renewable energy sources.<sup id="cite_ref-206" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-206">[206]</a></sup> A nuclear plant needs to be disassembled and removed. Much of the disassembled nuclear plant needs to be stored as low level nuclear waste.<sup id="cite_ref-207" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-207">[207]</a></sup>
</p>
<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="Nuclear_renaissance">Nuclear renaissance</span></h2>
<div class="thumb tleft"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:182px;"><a href="/wiki/File:OL3.jpg" title="File:OL3.jpg">File:OL3.jpg</a>  <div class="thumbcaption"><a href="/w/index.php?title=Olkiluoto_3&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Olkiluoto 3 (page does not exist)">Olkiluoto 3</a> under construction in 2009. It is the first <a href="/wiki/European_Pressurized_Reactor" title="European Pressurized Reactor">EPR</a> design, but problems with workmanship and supervision have created costly delays which led to an inquiry by the Finnish nuclear regulator <a href="/w/index.php?title=S%C3%A4teilyturvakeskus&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Säteilyturvakeskus (page does not exist)">STUK</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-wnn161009_208-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-wnn161009-208">[208]</a></sup> In December 2012, Areva estimated that the full cost of building the reactor will be about €8.5 billion, or almost three times the original delivery price of €3 billion.<sup id="cite_ref-209" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-209">[209]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-WNN-2012-07-17_210-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-WNN-2012-07-17-210">[210]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-BBC-2012-07-16_211-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-BBC-2012-07-16-211">[211]</a></sup></div></div></div>
<p><a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Rellink&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Rellink (page does not exist)">Template:Rellink</a>
</p><p>Since about 2001 the term <i>nuclear renaissance</i> has been used to refer to a possible nuclear power industry revival, driven by rising <a href="/w/index.php?title=Price_of_petroleum&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Price of petroleum (page does not exist)">fossil fuel prices</a> and new concerns about meeting <a href="/w/index.php?title=Greenhouse_gas&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Greenhouse gas (page does not exist)">greenhouse gas</a> emission limits.<sup id="cite_ref-intro_212-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-intro-212">[212]</a></sup> However, the <a href="/w/index.php?title=World_Nuclear_Association&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="World Nuclear Association (page does not exist)">World Nuclear Association</a> has reported that nuclear electricity generation in 2012 was at its lowest level since 1999.<sup id="cite_ref-wna13_213-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-wna13-213">[213]</a></sup>
</p><p>In March 2011 the <a href="/w/index.php?title=Timeline_of_the_Fukushima_nuclear_accidents&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Timeline of the Fukushima nuclear accidents (page does not exist)">nuclear emergencies</a> at Japan's <a href="/w/index.php?title=Fukushima_I_Nuclear_Power_Plant&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Fukushima I Nuclear Power Plant (page does not exist)">Fukushima I Nuclear Power Plant</a> and shutdowns at <a href="/w/index.php?title=2011_Japanese_nuclear_incidents&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="2011 Japanese nuclear incidents (page does not exist)">other nuclear facilities</a> raised questions among some commentators over the future of the renaissance.<sup id="cite_ref-214" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-214">[214]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-215" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-215">[215]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-216" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-216">[216]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-217" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-217">[217]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-218" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-218">[218]</a></sup> <a href="/w/index.php?title=Platts&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Platts (page does not exist)">Platts</a> has reported that "the crisis at Japan's Fukushima nuclear plants has prompted leading energy-consuming countries to review the safety of their existing reactors and cast doubt on the speed and scale of planned expansions around the world".<sup id="cite_ref-Platts_219-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Platts-219">[219]</a></sup> In 2011 <a href="/wiki/Siemens" title="Siemens">Siemens</a> exited the nuclear power sector following the <a href="/w/index.php?title=Fukushima_Daiichi_nuclear_disaster&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Fukushima Daiichi nuclear disaster (page does not exist)">Fukushima disaster</a> and subsequent changes to German energy policy, and supported the German government's planned <a href="/w/index.php?title=Energy_transition&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Energy transition (page does not exist)">energy transition</a> to <a href="/wiki/Renewable_energy" title="Renewable energy">renewable energy</a> technologies.<sup id="cite_ref-220" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-220">[220]</a></sup>  China, Germany, Switzerland, Israel, Malaysia, Thailand, United Kingdom, Italy<sup id="cite_ref-221" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-221">[221]</a></sup> and the Philippines have reviewed their nuclear power programs. Indonesia and Vietnam still plan to build nuclear power plants.<sup id="cite_ref-222" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-222">[222]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-223" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-223">[223]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-piersmorgan.blogs.cnn.com_224-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-piersmorgan.blogs.cnn.com-224">[224]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-news.xinhuanet.com_225-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-news.xinhuanet.com-225">[225]</a></sup> Countries such as <a href="/w/index.php?title=Nuclear_power_in_Australia&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Nuclear power in Australia (page does not exist)">Australia</a>, <a href="/w/index.php?title=Nuclear_energy_in_Austria&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Nuclear energy in Austria (page does not exist)">Austria</a>, <a href="/w/index.php?title=Nuclear_energy_in_Denmark&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Nuclear energy in Denmark (page does not exist)">Denmark</a>, <a href="/w/index.php?title=Nuclear_energy_in_Greece&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Nuclear energy in Greece (page does not exist)">Greece</a>, <a href="/w/index.php?title=Nuclear_energy_in_Ireland&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Nuclear energy in Ireland (page does not exist)">Ireland</a>, <a href="/wiki/Latvia" title="Latvia">Latvia</a>, <a href="/wiki/Liechtenstein" title="Liechtenstein">Liechtenstein</a>, <a href="/w/index.php?title=Nuclear_energy_in_Luxembourg&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Nuclear energy in Luxembourg (page does not exist)">Luxembourg</a>, <a href="/w/index.php?title=Nuclear_energy_in_Portugal&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Nuclear energy in Portugal (page does not exist)">Portugal</a>, <a href="/w/index.php?title=Nuclear_power_in_Israel&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Nuclear power in Israel (page does not exist)">Israel</a>, <a href="/w/index.php?title=Nuclear_energy_in_Malaysia&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Nuclear energy in Malaysia (page does not exist)">Malaysia</a>, <a href="/w/index.php?title=New_Zealand%27s_nuclear-free_zone&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="New Zealand's nuclear-free zone (page does not exist)">New Zealand</a>, and <a href="/w/index.php?title=Nuclear_energy_in_Norway&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Nuclear energy in Norway (page does not exist)">Norway</a> remain opposed to nuclear power. Following the Fukushima I nuclear accidents, the <a href="/wiki/International_Energy_Agency" title="International Energy Agency">International Energy Agency</a> halved its estimate of additional nuclear generating capacity built by 2035.<sup id="cite_ref-economist-20110428_34-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-economist-20110428-34">[34]</a></sup>
</p><p>The World Nuclear Association has said that “nuclear power generation suffered its biggest ever one-year fall through 2012 as the bulk of the Japanese fleet remained offline for a full calendar year”. Data from the <a href="/wiki/International_Atomic_Energy_Agency" title="International Atomic Energy Agency">International Atomic Energy Agency</a> showed that nuclear power plants globally produced 2346 TWh of electricity in 2012 – seven per cent less than in 2011. The figures illustrate the effects of a full year of 48 Japanese power reactors producing no power during the year. The permanent closure of eight reactor units in Germany was also a factor. Problems at Crystal River, Fort Calhoun and the two San Onofre units in the USA meant they produced no power for the full year, while in Belgium Doel 3 and Tihange 2 were out of action for six months. Compared to 2010, the nuclear industry produced 11% less electricity in 2012.<sup id="cite_ref-wna13_213-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-wna13-213">[213]</a></sup>
</p>
<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="Future_of_the_industry">Future of the industry</span></h2>
<p><a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Rellink&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Rellink (page does not exist)">Template:Rellink</a>
</p>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:182px;"><a href="/wiki/File:Brunswick-Nuclear-Plant-Discharge-Canal.jpg" title="File:Brunswick-Nuclear-Plant-Discharge-Canal.jpg">File:Brunswick-Nuclear-Plant-Discharge-Canal.jpg</a>  <div class="thumbcaption">Brunswick Nuclear Plant discharge canal</div></div></div>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:182px;"><a href="/wiki/File:Bruce-Nuclear-Szmurlo.jpg" title="File:Bruce-Nuclear-Szmurlo.jpg">File:Bruce-Nuclear-Szmurlo.jpg</a>  <div class="thumbcaption">The <a href="/wiki/Bruce_Nuclear_Generating_Station" title="Bruce Nuclear Generating Station">Bruce Nuclear Generating Station</a>, the <a href="/w/index.php?title=List_of_nuclear_power_stations&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="List of nuclear power stations (page does not exist)">largest nuclear power facility</a> in the world<sup id="cite_ref-Bruce_226-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Bruce-226">[226]</a></sup></div></div></div>
<p>As already noted, the nuclear power industry in western nations has a history of construction delays, <a href="/wiki/Olkiluoto_Nuclear_Power_Plant" title="Olkiluoto Nuclear Power Plant">cost overruns</a>, <a href="/w/index.php?title=List_of_canceled_nuclear_plants_in_the_United_States&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="List of canceled nuclear plants in the United States (page does not exist)">plant cancellations</a>, and <a href="/w/index.php?title=Nuclear_safety&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Nuclear safety (page does not exist)">nuclear safety</a> issues despite <a href="/wiki/Nuclear_Power_2010_Program" title="Nuclear Power 2010 Program">significant government subsidies and support</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-ReferenceA_86-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-ReferenceA-86">[86]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-jk_227-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-jk-227">[227]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-greeninc_228-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-greeninc-228">[228]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-rb_229-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-rb-229">[229]</a></sup>  In December 2013, <a href="/wiki/Forbes_Magazine" title="Forbes Magazine" class="mw-redirect">Forbes Magazine</a> reported that, in developed countries, “reactors are not a viable source of new power”.<sup id="cite_ref-jmc_230-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-jmc-230">[230]</a></sup> Even in developed nations where they make economic sense, they are not feasible because nuclear’s “enormous costs, political and <a href="/w/index.php?title=Anti-nuclear_movement&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Anti-nuclear movement (page does not exist)">popular opposition</a>, and regulatory uncertainty”.<sup id="cite_ref-jmc_230-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-jmc-230">[230]</a></sup> This view echoes the statement of former Exelon CEO <a href="/w/index.php?title=John_Rowe_(Exelon)&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="John Rowe (Exelon) (page does not exist)">John Rowe</a>, who said in 2012 that new nuclear plants “don’t make any sense right now” and won’t be economically viable in the foreseeable future.<sup id="cite_ref-jmc_230-2" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-jmc-230">[230]</a></sup> <a href="/w/index.php?title=John_Quiggin&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="John Quiggin (page does not exist)">John Quiggin</a>, economics professor, also says the main problem with the nuclear option is that it is not economically-viable. Quiggin says that we need more <a href="/w/index.php?title=Efficient_energy_use&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Efficient energy use (page does not exist)">efficient energy use</a> and more <a href="/w/index.php?title=Renewable_energy_commercialization&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Renewable energy commercialization (page does not exist)">renewable energy commercialization</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-231" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-231">[231]</a></sup> Former NRC member <a href="/w/index.php?title=Peter_Bradford&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Peter Bradford (page does not exist)">Peter Bradford</a> and Professor <a href="/w/index.php?title=Ian_Lowe&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Ian Lowe (page does not exist)">Ian Lowe</a> have recently made similar statements.<sup id="cite_ref-Hannah_Northey_232-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Hannah_Northey-232">[232]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-lowenuke_233-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-lowenuke-233">[233]</a></sup> However, some “nuclear cheerleaders” and lobbyists in the West continue to champion reactors, often with proposed new but largely untested designs, as a source of new power.<sup id="cite_ref-jmc_230-3" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-jmc-230">[230]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-Hannah_Northey_232-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Hannah_Northey-232">[232]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-leoh_234-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-leoh-234">[234]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-Diane_Farseta_38.E2.80.9356_235-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Diane_Farseta_38.E2.80.9356-235">[235]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-The_Nuclear_Charm_Offensive_236-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-The_Nuclear_Charm_Offensive-236">[236]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-ucsusa.org_237-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-ucsusa.org-237">[237]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-businessweek.com_238-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-businessweek.com-238">[238]</a></sup>
</p><p>Much more new build activity is occurring in developing countries like South Korea, India and China. China has 25 reactors under construction, with plans to build more,<sup id="cite_ref-Nuclear_Power_in_China_239-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Nuclear_Power_in_China-239">[239]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-240" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-240">[240]</a></sup> However, according to a government research unit, China must not build "too many nuclear power reactors too quickly", in order to avoid a shortfall of fuel, equipment and qualified plant workers.<sup id="cite_ref-241" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-241">[241]</a></sup>
</p><p>In the <a href="/wiki/USA" title="USA" class="mw-redirect">USA</a>, licenses of almost half its reactors have been extended to 60&#160;years,<sup id="cite_ref-world-nuclear_242-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-world-nuclear-242">[242]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-matt2010_243-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-matt2010-243">[243]</a></sup> Two new <a href="/w/index.php?title=Generation_III_reactor&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Generation III reactor (page does not exist)">Generation III reactors</a> are under construction at <a href="/w/index.php?title=Vogtle&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Vogtle (page does not exist)">Vogtle</a>, a dual construction project which marks the end of a 34 year period of stagnation in the US construction of civil nuclear power reactors. The station operator licenses of almost half the present 104 power reactors in the US, as of 2008, have been given <a href="/w/index.php?title=Light_Water_Reactor_Sustainability_Program&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Light Water Reactor Sustainability Program (page does not exist)">extensions to 60&#160;years</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-world-nuclear_242-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-world-nuclear-242">[242]</a></sup> As of 2012, U.S. nuclear industry officials expect five new reactors to enter service by 2020, all at existing plants.<sup id="cite_ref-us12_30-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-us12-30">[30]</a></sup> In 2013, four aging, uncompetitive, reactors were permanently closed.<sup id="cite_ref-Mark_Cooper_31-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Mark_Cooper-31">[31]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-mw11111_32-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-mw11111-32">[32]</a></sup> Relevant state legislatures are trying to close <a href="/wiki/Vermont_Yankee" title="Vermont Yankee" class="mw-redirect">Vermont Yankee</a> and <a href="/wiki/Indian_Point_Energy_Center" title="Indian Point Energy Center">Indian Point Nuclear Power Plant</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-mw11111_32-2" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-mw11111-32">[32]</a></sup>
</p><p>The U.S. NRC and the U.S. Department of Energy have initiated research into <a href="/w/index.php?title=Light_water_reactor_sustainability&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Light water reactor sustainability (page does not exist)">Light water reactor sustainability</a> which is hoped will lead to allowing extensions of reactor licenses beyond 60 years, provided that safety can be maintained, as the loss in non-CO<sub>2</sub>-emitting generation capacity by retiring reactors "may serve to challenge U.S. energy security, potentially resulting in increased <a href="/w/index.php?title=Greenhouse_gas&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Greenhouse gas (page does not exist)">greenhouse gas</a> emissions, and contributing to an imbalance between electric supply and demand."<sup id="cite_ref-LifeAfter60_244-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-LifeAfter60-244">[244]</a></sup>
</p><p>There is a possible impediment to production of nuclear power plants as only a few companies worldwide have the capacity to forge single-piece reactor pressure vessels,<sup id="cite_ref-245" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-245">[245]</a></sup> which are necessary in the most common reactor designs. Utilities across the world are submitting orders years in advance of any actual need for these vessels. Other manufacturers are examining various options, including making the component themselves, or finding ways to make a similar item using alternate methods.<sup id="cite_ref-246" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-246">[246]</a></sup>
