</p><p>According to the <a href="/w/index.php?title=World_Nuclear_Association&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="World Nuclear Association (page does not exist)">World Nuclear Association</a>, globally during the 1980s one new nuclear reactor started up every 17&#160;days on average, and by the year 2015 this rate could increase to one every 5&#160;days.<sup id="cite_ref-247" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-247">[247]</a></sup> As of 2007, <a href="/wiki/Watts_Bar_Nuclear_Generating_Station" title="Watts Bar Nuclear Generating Station">Watts Bar 1</a> in Tennessee, which came on-line on February 7, 1996, was the last U.S. commercial nuclear reactor to go on-line. This is often quoted as evidence of a successful worldwide campaign for nuclear power phase-out.<sup id="cite_ref-INL_248-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-INL-248">[248]</a></sup> <a href="/w/index.php?title=Electricity_shortage&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Electricity shortage (page does not exist)">Electricity shortages</a>, fossil fuel price increases, <a href="/w/index.php?title=Global_warming&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Global warming (page does not exist)">global warming</a>, and heavy metal emissions from fossil fuel use, new technology such as <a href="/w/index.php?title=Passively_safe&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Passively safe (page does not exist)">passively safe</a> plants, and national energy security may renew the demand for nuclear power plants.
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Nuclear_phase_out">Nuclear phase out</span></h3>
<p><a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Rellink&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Rellink (page does not exist)">Template:Rellink</a>
</p>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:182px;"><a href="/wiki/File:Atom-Moratorium.svg" title="File:Atom-Moratorium.svg">File:Atom-Moratorium.svg</a>  <div class="thumbcaption">Eight of the seventeen operating reactors in Germany were permanently shut down following the March 2011 <a href="/w/index.php?title=Fukushima_nuclear_disaster&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Fukushima nuclear disaster (page does not exist)">Fukushima nuclear disaster</a>.</div></div></div>
<p>Following the Fukushima Daiichi nuclear disaster, the <a href="/wiki/International_Energy_Agency" title="International Energy Agency">International Energy Agency</a> halved its estimate of additional nuclear generating capacity to be built by 2035.<sup id="cite_ref-economist-20110428_34-2" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-economist-20110428-34">[34]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-late_35-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-late-35">[35]</a></sup> <a href="/w/index.php?title=Platts&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Platts (page does not exist)">Platts</a> has reported that "the crisis at Japan's Fukushima nuclear plants has prompted leading energy-consuming countries to review the safety of their existing reactors and cast doubt on the speed and scale of planned expansions around the world".<sup id="cite_ref-Platts_219-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Platts-219">[219]</a></sup> In 2011, <i>The Economist</i> reported that nuclear power "looks dangerous, unpopular, expensive and risky", and that "it is replaceable with relative ease and could be forgone with no huge structural shifts in the way the world works".<sup id="cite_ref-econ2011_249-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-econ2011-249">[249]</a></sup>
</p><p>In early April 2011, analysts at Swiss-based investment bank UBS said: "At Fukushima, four reactors have been out of control for weeks, casting doubt on whether even an advanced economy can master nuclear safety . . .. We believe the Fukushima accident was the most serious ever for the credibility of nuclear power".<sup id="cite_ref-250" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-250">[250]</a></sup>
</p><p>In 2011, <a href="/wiki/Deutsche_Bank" title="Deutsche Bank">Deutsche Bank</a> analysts concluded that "the global impact of the Fukushima accident is a fundamental shift in public perception with regard to how a nation prioritizes and values its populations health, safety, security, and natural environment when determining its current and future energy pathways". As a consequence, "<a href="/wiki/Renewable_energy" title="Renewable energy">renewable energy</a> will be a clear long-term winner in most energy systems, a conclusion supported by many voter surveys conducted over the past few weeks. At the same time, we consider <a href="/wiki/Natural_gas" title="Natural gas">natural gas</a> to be, at the very least, an important transition fuel, especially in those regions where it is considered secure".<sup id="cite_ref-251" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-251">[251]</a></sup>
</p><p>In September 2011, German engineering giant <a href="/wiki/Siemens" title="Siemens">Siemens</a> announced it will withdraw entirely from the nuclear industry, as a response to the <a href="/w/index.php?title=Fukushima_nuclear_disaster&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Fukushima nuclear disaster (page does not exist)">Fukushima nuclear disaster</a> in Japan, and said that it would no longer build nuclear power plants anywhere in the world. The company’s chairman, Peter Löscher, said that "Siemens was ending plans to cooperate with Rosatom, the Russian state-controlled nuclear power company, in the construction of dozens of nuclear plants throughout Russia over the coming two decades".<sup id="cite_ref-252" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-252">[252]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-253" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-253">[253]</a></sup> Also in September 2011, IAEA Director General Yukiya Amano said the Japanese nuclear disaster "caused deep public anxiety throughout the world and damaged confidence in nuclear power".<sup id="cite_ref-254" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-254">[254]</a></sup>
</p><p>In February 2012, the United States <a href="/wiki/Nuclear_Regulatory_Commission" title="Nuclear Regulatory Commission">Nuclear Regulatory Commission</a> approved the construction of two additional reactors at the <a href="/wiki/Vogtle_Electric_Generating_Plant" title="Vogtle Electric Generating Plant">Vogtle Electric Generating Plant</a>, the first reactors to be approved in over 30 years since the Three Mile Island accident,<sup id="cite_ref-yah12_255-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-yah12-255">[255]</a></sup> but NRC Chairman <a href="/w/index.php?title=Gregory_Jaczko&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Gregory Jaczko (page does not exist)">Gregory Jaczko</a> cast a dissenting vote citing safety concerns stemming from Japan's 2011 Fukushima nuclear disaster, and saying "I cannot support issuing this license as if Fukushima never happened".<sup id="cite_ref-us12_30-2" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-us12-30">[30]</a></sup> One week after Southern received the license to begin major construction on the two new reactors, a dozen environmental and <a href="/w/index.php?title=Anti-nuclear&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Anti-nuclear (page does not exist)">anti-nuclear</a> groups are suing to stop the Plant Vogtle expansion project, saying "public safety and environmental problems since Japan's Fukushima Daiichi nuclear reactor accident have not been taken into account".<sup id="cite_ref-256" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-256">[256]</a></sup>
</p><p>Countries such as <a href="/w/index.php?title=Anti-nuclear_movement_in_Australia&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Anti-nuclear movement in Australia (page does not exist)">Australia</a>, <a href="/w/index.php?title=Anti-nuclear_movement_in_Austria&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Anti-nuclear movement in Austria (page does not exist)">Austria</a>,  <a href="/w/index.php?title=Nuclear_energy_in_Denmark&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Nuclear energy in Denmark (page does not exist)">Denmark</a>, <a href="/w/index.php?title=Nuclear_energy_in_Greece&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Nuclear energy in Greece (page does not exist)">Greece</a>, <a href="/w/index.php?title=Nuclear_energy_in_Ireland&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Nuclear energy in Ireland (page does not exist)">Ireland</a>, <a href="/w/index.php?title=Nuclear_energy_in_Italy&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Nuclear energy in Italy (page does not exist)">Italy</a>, Latvia, Liechtenstein, <a href="/w/index.php?title=Nuclear_energy_in_Luxembourg&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Nuclear energy in Luxembourg (page does not exist)">Luxembourg</a>, <a href="/w/index.php?title=Nuclear_energy_in_Malta&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Nuclear energy in Malta (page does not exist)">Malta</a>, <a href="/w/index.php?title=Nuclear_energy_in_Portugal&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Nuclear energy in Portugal (page does not exist)">Portugal</a>, <a href="/w/index.php?title=Nuclear_power_in_Israel&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Nuclear power in Israel (page does not exist)">Israel</a>, <a href="/w/index.php?title=Nuclear_energy_in_Malaysia&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Nuclear energy in Malaysia (page does not exist)">Malaysia</a>, <a href="/w/index.php?title=New_Zealand%27s_nuclear-free_zone&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="New Zealand's nuclear-free zone (page does not exist)">New Zealand</a>, and <a href="/w/index.php?title=Nuclear_energy_in_Norway&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Nuclear energy in Norway (page does not exist)">Norway</a> have no nuclear power reactors and remain opposed to nuclear power.<sup id="cite_ref-econ2011_249-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-econ2011-249">[249]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-gl2011_257-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-gl2011-257">[257]</a></sup> However, by contrast, some countries remain in favor, and financially support <a href="/wiki/Nuclear_fusion" title="Nuclear fusion">nuclear fusion</a> research, including <a href="/wiki/EU" title="EU" class="mw-redirect">EU</a> wide funding of the <a href="/wiki/ITER" title="ITER">ITER</a> project.<sup id="cite_ref-258" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-258">[258]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-259" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-259">[259]</a></sup>
</p><p>Worldwide wind power has been increasing at 26%/year, and solar power at 58%/year, from 2006 to 2011, as a replacement for thermal generation of electricity.<sup id="cite_ref-260" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-260">[260]</a></sup>
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Advanced_concepts">Advanced concepts</span></h3>
<p><a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Rellink&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Rellink (page does not exist)">Template:Rellink</a>
</p><p>Current fission reactors in operation around the world are second or third generation systems, with most of the first-generation systems having been retired some time ago. Research into advanced generation IV reactor types was officially started by the Generation IV International Forum (GIF) based on eight technology goals, including to improve nuclear safety, improve proliferation resistance, minimize waste, improve natural resource utilization, the ability to consume existing nuclear waste in the production of electricity, and decrease the cost to build and run such plants. Most of these reactors differ significantly from current operating light water reactors, and are generally not expected to be available for commercial construction before 2030.<sup id="cite_ref-261" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-261">[261]</a></sup>
</p><p>The nuclear reactors to be built at Vogtle are new <a href="/w/index.php?title=AP1000&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="AP1000 (page does not exist)">AP1000</a> third generation reactors, which are said to have safety improvements over older power reactors.<sup id="cite_ref-yah12_255-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-yah12-255">[255]</a></sup> However, John Ma, a senior structural engineer at the NRC, is concerned that some parts of the AP1000 steel skin are so brittle that the "impact energy" from a plane strike or storm driven projectile could shatter the wall.<sup id="cite_ref-bs11_262-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-bs11-262">[262]</a></sup> Edwin Lyman, a senior staff scientist at the <a href="/wiki/Union_of_Concerned_Scientists" title="Union of Concerned Scientists">Union of Concerned Scientists</a>, is concerned about the strength of the steel containment vessel and the concrete shield building around the AP1000.<sup id="cite_ref-bs11_262-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-bs11-262">[262]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-mlw_263-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-mlw-263">[263]</a></sup>
</p><p>The <a href="/wiki/Union_of_Concerned_Scientists" title="Union of Concerned Scientists">Union of Concerned Scientists</a> has referred to the <a href="/wiki/European_Pressurized_Reactor" title="European Pressurized Reactor">European Pressurized Reactor</a>, currently under construction in China, Finland and France, as the only new reactor design under consideration in the United States that "...appears to have the potential to be significantly safer and more secure against attack than today's reactors."<sup id="cite_ref-NPIAWW_264-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-NPIAWW-264">[264]</a></sup>
</p><p>One disadvantage of any new reactor technology is that safety risks may be greater initially as reactor operators have little experience with the new design.  Nuclear engineer <a href="/w/index.php?title=David_Lochbaum&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="David Lochbaum (page does not exist)">David Lochbaum</a> has explained that almost all serious nuclear accidents have occurred with what was at the time the most recent technology. He argues that "the problem with new reactors and accidents is twofold: scenarios arise that are impossible to plan for in simulations; and humans make mistakes".<sup id="cite_ref-safe_265-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-safe-265">[265]</a></sup> As one director of a U.S. research laboratory put it, "fabrication, construction, operation, and maintenance of new reactors will face a steep learning curve: advanced technologies will have a heightened risk of accidents and mistakes. The technology may be proven, but people are not".<sup id="cite_ref-safe_265-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-safe-265">[265]</a></sup>
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Hybrid_nuclear_fusion-fission">Hybrid nuclear fusion-fission</span></h3>
<p><a href="/w/index.php?title=Hybrid_nuclear_power&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Hybrid nuclear power (page does not exist)">Hybrid nuclear power</a> is a proposed means of generating <a href="/w/index.php?title=Electrical_power_industry&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Electrical power industry (page does not exist)">power</a>  by use of a combination of <a href="/wiki/Nuclear_fusion" title="Nuclear fusion">nuclear fusion</a> and <a href="/wiki/Nuclear_fission" title="Nuclear fission">fission</a> processes. The concept dates to the 1950s, and was briefly advocated by <a href="/wiki/Hans_Bethe" title="Hans Bethe">Hans Bethe</a> during the 1970s, but largely remained unexplored until a revival of interest in 2009, due to delays in the realization of pure fusion. When a sustained nuclear fusion power plant is built, it has the potential to be capable of extracting all the fission energy that remains in <a href="/w/index.php?title=Spent_nuclear_fuel&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Spent nuclear fuel (page does not exist)">spent fission fuel</a>, reducing the volume of nuclear waste by orders of magnitude, and more importantly, eliminating all <a href="/wiki/Actinide" title="Actinide">actinides</a> present in the spent fuel, substances which cause security concerns.<sup id="cite_ref-hybrid_266-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-hybrid-266">[266]</a></sup>
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Nuclear_fusion">Nuclear fusion</span></h3>
<p><a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Rellink&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Rellink (page does not exist)">Template:Rellink</a>
<a href="/wiki/Fusion_power" title="Fusion power">Nuclear fusion</a> reactions have the potential to be safer and generate less radioactive waste than fission.<sup id="cite_ref-267" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-267">[267]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-WorldEnergyCouncil_268-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-WorldEnergyCouncil-268">[268]</a></sup> These reactions appear potentially viable, though technically quite difficult and have yet to be created on a scale that could be used in a functional power plant. Fusion power has been under theoretical and experimental investigation since the 1950s.
</p><p>Construction of the <a href="/wiki/International_Thermonuclear_Experimental_Reactor" title="International Thermonuclear Experimental Reactor" class="mw-redirect">International Thermonuclear Experimental Reactor</a> facility began in 2007, but the project has run into many delays and budget overruns. The facility is now not expected to begin operations until the year 2027 – 11 years after initially anticipated.<sup id="cite_ref-269" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-269">[269]</a></sup> A follow on commercial nuclear <a href="/wiki/Fusion_power" title="Fusion power">fusion power</a> station, <a href="/w/index.php?title=DEMO&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="DEMO (page does not exist)">DEMO</a>, has been proposed.<sup id="cite_ref-ITERorg_9-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-ITERorg-9">[9]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-EFDA_Activities_270-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-EFDA_Activities-270">[270]</a></sup> There is also suggestions for a power plant based upon a different fusion approach, that of a <a href="/w/index.php?title=Inertial_fusion_power_plant&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Inertial fusion power plant (page does not exist)">Inertial fusion power plant</a>.
</p><p>Fusion powered electricity generation was initially believed to be readily achievable, as fission power had been. However, the extreme requirements for continuous reactions and <a href="/w/index.php?title=Plasma_containment&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Plasma containment (page does not exist)">plasma containment</a> led to projections being extended by several decades. In 2010, more than 60 years after the first attempts, commercial power production was still believed to be unlikely before 2050.<sup id="cite_ref-ITERorg_9-2" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-ITERorg-9">[9]</a></sup>
</p>
